<p><b>Banc of America Securities LLC</b> (<b>BAS</b>), was the <a href="/wiki/Investment_banking" title="Investment banking">investment banking</a> subsidiary of BoA from 1998 until BoA was merged with <a href="/wiki/Merrill_Lynch" class="mw-redirect" title="Merrill Lynch">Merrill Lynch</a> (2008).  Headquartered in New York City, the company competed in both the domestic and international equity and investment banking markets. The company was a registered <a href="/wiki/Broker-dealer" title="Broker-dealer">broker-dealer</a> with the <a href="/wiki/United_States_Securities_and_Exchange_Commission" class="mw-redirect" title="United States Securities and Exchange Commission">United States Securities and Exchange Commission</a> (SEC) and was a member of the <a href="/wiki/New_York_Stock_Exchange" title="New York Stock Exchange">New York Stock Exchange</a> and the <a href="/wiki/National_Association_of_Securities_Dealers" class="mw-redirect" title="National Association of Securities Dealers">National Association of Securities Dealers</a>. The use of "<a href="/wiki/Banc" class="mw-redirect" title="Banc">Banc</a>" in the BAS's name was indicative of the fact that the company was not a <a href="/wiki/Bank" title="Bank">bank</a>, and its deposits and other holdings were not insured by the <a href="/wiki/Federal_Deposit_Insurance_Corporation" title="Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation">Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation</a>.
</p><p>The subsidiary was founded in 1998 following a strategy pioneered by <a href="/wiki/Citigroup" title="Citigroup">Citigroup</a> that combines corporate lending with investment banking advice and services.<sup id="cite_ref-43" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-43"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>43<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> During its years of operation its strongest investment banking groups included <a href="/wiki/High-yield_debt" title="High-yield debt">high-yield debt</a> underwriting and Leveraged Finance, in addition to industry coverage groups such as Healthcare, Consumer & Retail, Global Industries, Media & Telecom, Financial Institutions, Real Estate and Gaming. BAS also did a significant amount of work for Financial Sponsors, or private equity firms, often financing leveraged transactions. On the product side, the firm employed M&A senior bankers throughout the industry coverage groups.  BAS also had a stand-alone <a href="/wiki/Mergers_%26_Acquisitions" title="Mergers & Acquisitions">Mergers & Acquisitions</a> Group, consisting of bankers that transact M&A deals across all industries, as well as a Transaction Development Group, which aimed to identify and market transaction opportunities. The unit also had sizeable fixed income, currency and commodities divisions.
</p><p>During 20072008, BAS significantly downsized its international operations, eliminating a number of industry groups in Europe, as well as cutting numerous banking and sales and trading positions in North America and Asia prior to its merger with Merrill Lynch. On October 3, 2008, Bank of America announced that <a href="/wiki/John_Thain" title="John Thain">John Thain</a> would lead the combined Bank of America/<a href="/wiki/Merrill_Lynch" class="mw-redirect" title="Merrill Lynch">Merrill Lynch</a> Global Corporate and Investment Banking enterprise. Thain was forced out by Bank of America Chairman <a href="/wiki/Ken_Lewis_(executive)" title="Ken Lewis (executive)">Kenneth D. Lewis</a> on January 22, 2009, because of the colossal losses visited on B of A due to its acquisition of Merrill Lynch.<sup id="cite_ref-Creswell2009-1-23_44-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Creswell2009-1-23-44"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>44<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> With Thain's departure, <a href="/wiki/Brian_Moynihan" title="Brian Moynihan">Brian Moynihan</a> became president of Global Banking and Global Wealth and Investment Management.<sup id="cite_ref-Creswell2009-1-23_44-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Creswell2009-1-23-44"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>44<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> After the merger was closed, the SEC Registration of Banc of America Securities was terminated in January 2011.
</p><p>BAS operated from a number of offices across the world, with major offices in <a href="/wiki/New_York,_New_York" class="mw-redirect" title="New York, New York">New York, New York</a>, <a href="/wiki/Charlotte,_North_Carolina" title="Charlotte, North Carolina">Charlotte, North Carolina</a>, <a href="/wiki/Chicago,_Illinois" class="mw-redirect" title="Chicago, Illinois">Chicago, Illinois</a>, <a href="/wiki/San_Francisco,_California" class="mw-redirect" title="San Francisco, California">San Francisco, California</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tokyo" title="Tokyo">Tokyo</a>, <a href="/wiki/Frankfurt" title="Frankfurt">Frankfurt</a>, <a href="/wiki/London" title="London">London</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Mumbai" title="Mumbai">Mumbai</a>. The bulk of its investment banking operations eventually moved to the <a href="/wiki/Bank_of_America_Tower,_New_York_City" class="mw-redirect" title="Bank of America Tower, New York City">Bank of America Tower</a>, a $1 billion, 58-story skyscraper, at <a href="/wiki/Bryant_Park" title="Bryant Park">Bryant Park</a> in New York City that was completed in 2009. Prior to that, BAS in New York had offices in various locations due to the numerous mergers that had taken place over the previous decade, including space at 9 West 57th Street, <a href="/wiki/List_of_tenants_in_1_World_Trade_Center_(1971%E2%80%932001)" class="mw-redirect" title="List of tenants in 1 World Trade Center (19712001)">1 World Trade Center</a>, 1633 Broadway, 40 East 52nd Street, 335 Madison Avenue, and 100 West 33rd Street.
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="2005_to_2007">2005 to 2007</h3><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Bank_of_America&action=edit&section=7" title="Edit section: 2005 to 2007"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Porter_Ranch_Bank_of_America.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5d/Porter_Ranch_Bank_of_America.jpg/250px-Porter_Ranch_Bank_of_America.jpg" decoding="async" width="250" height="155" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5d/Porter_Ranch_Bank_of_America.jpg/500px-Porter_Ranch_Bank_of_America.jpg 1.5x" data-file-width="1000" data-file-height="621"></a><figcaption>A typical Bank of America branch in <a href="/wiki/Los_Angeles" title="Los Angeles">Los Angeles</a></figcaption></figure>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Hoboken,_N.J.,_Nov._3,_2012_--_Bank_of_America_and_other_banks_have_set_up_mobile_ATMs_for_survivors_of_Hurricane_Sandy_get_cash_to_spend_at_stores_that_are_open_for_cash_customers._-_DPLA_-_def08f331beecb7cc3210f2c013d1a7a.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img alt="Mobile ATM" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/39/Hoboken%2C_N.J.%2C_Nov._3%2C_2012_--_Bank_of_America_and_other_banks_have_set_up_mobile_ATMs_for_survivors_of_Hurricane_Sandy_get_cash_to_spend_at_stores_that_are_open_for_cash_customers._-_DPLA_-_def08f331beecb7cc3210f2c013d1a7a.jpg/250px-thumbnail.jpg" decoding="async" width="250" height="377" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/39/Hoboken%2C_N.J.%2C_Nov._3%2C_2012_--_Bank_of_America_and_other_banks_have_set_up_mobile_ATMs_for_survivors_of_Hurricane_Sandy_get_cash_to_spend_at_stores_that_are_open_for_cash_customers._-_DPLA_-_def08f331beecb7cc3210f2c013d1a7a.jpg/500px-thumbnail.jpg 1.5x" data-file-width="3118" data-file-height="4706"></a><figcaption>Emergency ATMs put in place in <a href="/wiki/Hoboken,_New_Jersey" title="Hoboken, New Jersey">Hoboken, New Jersey</a> following <a href="/wiki/Hurricane_Sandy" title="Hurricane Sandy">Hurricane Sandy</a> in 2012</figcaption></figure>
<p>In 2001, McColl stepped down as CEO and named <a href="/wiki/Ken_Lewis_(executive)" title="Ken Lewis (executive)">Ken Lewis</a> as his successor. In 2004, Bank of America announced it would purchase Boston-based bank <a href="/wiki/FleetBoston_Financial" title="FleetBoston Financial">FleetBoston Financial</a> for $47 billion in cash and stock.<sup id="cite_ref-fleetboston-merger_45-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-fleetboston-merger-45"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>45<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> By merging with Bank of America, all of its banks and branches were given the Bank of America logo. At the time of merger, FleetBoston was the seventh largest bank in United States with $197 billion in assets, over 20 million customers and revenue of $12 billion.<sup id="cite_ref-fleetboston-merger_45-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-fleetboston-merger-45"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>45<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Hundreds of FleetBoston workers lost their jobs or were demoted, according to <i><a href="/wiki/The_Boston_Globe" title="The Boston Globe">The Boston Globe</a></i>.
</p><p>On June 30, 2005, Bank of America announced it would purchase credit card giant <a href="/wiki/MBNA" title="MBNA">MBNA</a> for $35  billion in cash and stock. The <a href="/wiki/Federal_Reserve_Board" class="mw-redirect" title="Federal Reserve Board">Federal Reserve Board</a> gave final approval to the merger on December 15, 2005, and the merger closed on January 1, 2006. The acquisition of MBNA provided Bank of America a leading domestic and foreign credit card issuer. The combined Bank of America Card Services organization, including the former MBNA, had more than 40 million U.S. accounts and nearly $140 billion in outstanding balances. Under Bank of America, the operation was renamed FIA Card Services.
</p><p>Bank of America operated under the name BankBoston in many other Latin American countries, including Brazil. In May 2006, Bank of America and <a href="/wiki/Banco_Ita%C3%BA" title="Banco Ita">Banco Ita</a> (Investimentos Ita S.A.) entered into an acquisition agreement, through which Ita agreed to acquire BankBoston's operations in Brazil, and was granted an exclusive right to purchase Bank of America's operations in <a href="/wiki/Chile" title="Chile">Chile</a> and <a href="/wiki/Uruguay" title="Uruguay">Uruguay</a>, in exchange for Ita shares. The deal was signed in August 2006.
</p><p>Prior to the transaction, BankBoston's Brazilian operations included asset management, private banking, a credit card portfolio, and small, middle-market, and large corporate segments. It had 66 branches and 203,000 clients in Brazil. BankBoston in Chile had 44 branches and 58,000 clients and in Uruguay, it had 15 branches. In addition, there was a credit card company, OCA, in Uruguay, which had 23 branches. BankBoston N.A. in Uruguay, together with OCA, jointly served 372,000 clients. While the BankBoston name and trademarks were not part of the transaction, as part of the sale agreement, they cannot be used by Bank of America in Brazil, Chile or Uruguay following the transactions. Hence, the BankBoston name has disappeared from Brazil, Chile and Uruguay. The Ita stock received by Bank of America in the transactions has allowed Bank of America's stake in Ita to reach 11.51%. Banco de Boston de Brazil had been founded in 1947.
</p><p>On November 20, 2006, Bank of America announced the purchase of <a href="/wiki/The_United_States_Trust_Company" class="mw-redirect" title="The United States Trust Company">The United States Trust Company</a> for $3.3 billion, from the <a href="/wiki/Charles_Schwab_Corporation" title="Charles Schwab Corporation">Charles Schwab Corporation</a>. US Trust had about $100 billion of <a href="/wiki/Assets_under_management" title="Assets under management">assets under management</a> and over 150 years of experience. The deal closed July 1, 2007.<sup id="cite_ref-46" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-46"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>46<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>On September 14, 2007, Bank of America won approval from the Federal Reserve to acquire <a href="/wiki/LaSalle_Bank_Corporation" class="mw-redirect" title="LaSalle Bank Corporation">LaSalle Bank Corporation</a> from <a href="/wiki/ABN_AMRO" title="ABN AMRO">ABN AMRO</a> for $21 billion. With this purchase, Bank of America possessed $1.7 trillion in assets. A Dutch court blocked the sale until it was later approved in July. The acquisition was completed on October 1, 2007. Many of LaSalle's branches and offices had already taken over smaller regional banks within the previous decade, such as Lansing and Detroit-based <a href="/wiki/Michigan_National_Bank" title="Michigan National Bank">Michigan National Bank</a>. The acquisition also included the <a href="/wiki/Chicago_Marathon" title="Chicago Marathon">Chicago Marathon</a> event, which ABN AMRO acquired in 1996. Bank of America took over the event starting with the 2007 race.
</p><p>The deal increased Bank of America's presence in <a href="/wiki/Illinois" title="Illinois">Illinois</a>, <a href="/wiki/Michigan" title="Michigan">Michigan</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Indiana" title="Indiana">Indiana</a> by 411 branches, 17,000 commercial bank clients, 1.4 million retail customers, and 1,500 ATMs. Bank of America became the largest bank in the Chicago market with 197 offices and 14% of the deposit share, surpassing <a href="/wiki/JPMorgan_Chase" title="JPMorgan Chase">JPMorgan Chase</a>.
</p><p><a href="/wiki/LaSalle_Bank" title="LaSalle Bank">LaSalle Bank</a> and <a href="/wiki/LaSalle_Bank_Midwest" class="mw-redirect" title="LaSalle Bank Midwest">LaSalle Bank Midwest</a> branches adopted the Bank of America name on May 5, 2008.<sup id="cite_ref-47" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-47"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>47<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="20072010_(Subprime_mortgage_crisis)"><span id="2007.E2.80.932010_.28Subprime_mortgage_crisis.29"></span>20072010 (Subprime mortgage crisis)</h3><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Bank_of_America&action=edit&section=8" title="Edit section: 20072010 (Subprime mortgage crisis)"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<p>During the <a href="/wiki/Subprime_mortgage_crisis" title="Subprime mortgage crisis">subprime mortgage crisis</a>, the bank, under <a href="/wiki/Ken_Lewis_(executive)" title="Ken Lewis (executive)">Ken Lewis</a>, made two major acquisitions that would shape the future of the company for the next couple years coming out of the crisis. Specifically the bank was sued by many different parties and made to pay tens of billions of dollars.
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading4"><h4 id="Acquisition_of_Countrywide_Financial">Acquisition of Countrywide Financial</h4><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Bank_of_America&action=edit&section=9" title="Edit section: Acquisition of Countrywide Financial"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<p>On August 23, 2007, the company announced a $2 billion <a href="/wiki/Repurchase_agreement" title="Repurchase agreement">repurchase agreement</a> for <a href="/wiki/Countrywide_Financial" class="mw-redirect" title="Countrywide Financial">Countrywide Financial</a>. This purchase of <a href="/wiki/Preferred_stock" title="Preferred stock">preferred stock</a> was arranged to provide a <a href="/wiki/Return_on_investment" title="Return on investment">return on investment</a> of 7.25% <i><a href="/wiki/Per_annum" title="Per annum">per annum</a></i> and provided the option to purchase <a href="/wiki/Common_stock" title="Common stock">common stock</a> at a price of $18 per share.<sup id="cite_ref-48" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-48"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>48<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>On January 11, 2008, Bank of America announced that it would buy Countrywide Financial for $4.1 billion.<sup id="cite_ref-49" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-49"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>49<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> In March 2008, it was reported that the <a href="/wiki/Federal_Bureau_of_Investigation" title="Federal Bureau of Investigation">Federal Bureau of Investigation</a> (FBI) was investigating Countrywide for possible fraud relating to home loans and mortgages.<sup id="cite_ref-50" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-50"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>50<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> This news did not hinder the acquisition, which was completed in July 2008,<sup id="cite_ref-51" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-51"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>51<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> giving the bank a substantial market share of the mortgage business, and access to Countrywide's resources for servicing mortgages.<sup id="cite_ref-52" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-52"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>52<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The acquisition was seen as preventing a potential bankruptcy for Countrywide. Countrywide, however, denied that it was close to bankruptcy. Countrywide provided mortgage servicing for nine million mortgages valued at $1.4 trillion as of December 31, 2007.<sup id="cite_ref-53" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-53"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>53<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>This purchase made Bank of America Corporation the leading mortgage originator and servicer in the U.S., controlling 2025% of the home loan market.<sup id="cite_ref-54" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-54"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>54<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The deal was structured to merge Countrywide with the Red Oak Merger Corporation, which Bank of America created as an independent subsidiary. It has been suggested that the deal was structured this way to prevent a potential bankruptcy stemming from large losses in Countrywide hurting the parent organization by keeping Countrywide <a href="/wiki/Bankruptcy_remote" title="Bankruptcy remote">bankruptcy remote</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-55" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-55"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>55<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Countrywide Financial has changed its name to <a href="/wiki/Bank_of_America_Home_Loans" title="Bank of America Home Loans">Bank of America Home Loans</a>.
</p><p>In December 2011, the <a href="/wiki/United_States_Department_of_Justice" title="United States Department of Justice">Justice Department</a> announced a $335 million <a href="/wiki/Settlement_agreement" class="mw-redirect" title="Settlement agreement">settlement</a> with Bank of America over discriminatory lending practice at Countrywide Financial. <a href="/wiki/United_States_Attorney_General" title="United States Attorney General">Attorney General</a> <a href="/wiki/Eric_Holder" title="Eric Holder">Eric Holder</a> said a federal probe found <a href="/wiki/Mortgage_discrimination" title="Mortgage discrimination">discrimination</a> against qualified African-American and Latino borrowers from 2004 to 2008. He said that minority borrowers who qualified for <a href="/wiki/Prime_lending_rate" class="mw-redirect" title="Prime lending rate">prime loans</a> were steered into higher-interest-rate <a href="/wiki/Subprime_loans" class="mw-redirect" title="Subprime loans">subprime loans</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-56" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-56"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>56<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading4"><h4 id="Acquisition_of_Merrill_Lynch">Acquisition of Merrill Lynch</h4><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Bank_of_America&action=edit&section=10" title="Edit section: Acquisition of Merrill Lynch"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:BOAChart.svg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/43/BOAChart.svg/250px-BOAChart.svg.png" decoding="async" width="250" height="140" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/43/BOAChart.svg/500px-BOAChart.svg.png 1.5x" data-file-width="831" data-file-height="464"></a><figcaption>Chart showing the trajectory of Bank of America's share value and transaction volume during the <a href="/wiki/2008_financial_crisis" title="2008 financial crisis">2008 financial crisis</a></figcaption></figure>
<p>On September 14, 2008, Bank of America announced its intention to purchase <a href="/wiki/Merrill_Lynch" class="mw-redirect" title="Merrill Lynch">Merrill Lynch & Co., Inc.</a> in an all-stock deal worth approximately $50 billion. Merrill Lynch was at the time within days of collapse, and the acquisition effectively saved Merrill from bankruptcy.<sup id="cite_ref-57" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-57"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>57<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Around the same time Bank of America was reportedly also in talks to purchase <a href="/wiki/Lehman_Brothers" title="Lehman Brothers">Lehman Brothers</a>, however a lack of government guarantees caused the bank to abandon talks with Lehman.<sup id="cite_ref-58" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-58"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>58<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Lehman Brothers filed for bankruptcy the same day Bank of America announced its plans to acquire Merrill Lynch.<sup id="cite_ref-59" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-59"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>59<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> This acquisition made Bank of America the largest <a href="/wiki/Financial_services" title="Financial services">financial services</a> company in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-60" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-60"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>60<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Temasek_Holdings" class="mw-redirect" title="Temasek Holdings">Temasek Holdings</a>, the largest shareholder of Merrill Lynch & Co., Inc., briefly became one of the largest shareholders of Bank of America, with a 3% stake.<sup id="cite_ref-61" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-61"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>61<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> However, taking a loss <a href="/wiki/Reuters" title="Reuters">Reuters</a> estimated at $3 billion, the <a href="/wiki/Singapore" title="Singapore">Singapore</a> <a href="/wiki/Sovereign_wealth_fund" title="Sovereign wealth fund">sovereign wealth fund</a> sold its whole stake in Bank of America in the first quarter of 2009.<sup id="cite_ref-62" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-62"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>62<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Shareholders of both companies approved the acquisition on December 5, 2008, and the deal closed January 1, 2009.<sup id="cite_ref-63" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-63"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>63<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Bank of America had planned to retain various members of the then Merrill Lynch's CEO, <a href="/wiki/John_Thain" title="John Thain">John Thain</a>'s management team after the merger.<sup id="cite_ref-64" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-64"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>64<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> However, after Thain was removed from his position, most of his allies left. The departure of <a href="/wiki/Nelson_Chai" title="Nelson Chai">Nelson Chai</a>, who had been named Asia-Pacific president, left just one of Thain's hires in place: Tom Montag, head of sales and trading.<sup id="cite_ref-65" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-65"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>65<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>The bank, in its January 16, 2009, earnings release, revealed massive losses at Merrill Lynch in the fourth quarter, which necessitated an infusion of money that had previously been negotiated<sup id="cite_ref-66" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-66"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>66<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> with the government as part of the government-persuaded deal for the bank to acquire Merrill. Merrill recorded an operating loss of $21.5 billion in the quarter, mainly in its sales and trading operations, led by Tom Montag. The bank also disclosed it tried to abandon the deal in December after the extent of Merrill's trading losses surfaced, but was compelled to complete the merger by the U.S. government. The bank's stock price sank to $7.18, its lowest level in 17 years, after announcing earnings and the Merrill mishap. The market capitalization of Bank of America, including Merrill Lynch, was then $45 billion, less than the $50 billion it offered for Merrill just four months earlier, and down $108 billion from the merger announcement.
</p><p>Bank of America CEO Kenneth Lewis testified before Congress<sup id="cite_ref-ATLoffer_5-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ATLoffer-5"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>5<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> that he had some misgivings about the acquisition of Merrill Lynch and that federal official pressured him to proceed with the deal or face losing his job and endangering the bank's relationship with federal regulators.<sup id="cite_ref-67" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-67"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>67<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Lewis's statement is backed up by internal emails subpoenaed by Republican lawmakers on the House Oversight Committee.<sup id="cite_ref-68" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-68"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>68<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> In one of the emails, Richmond Federal Reserve President <a href="/wiki/Jeffrey_M._Lacker" title="Jeffrey M. Lacker">Jeffrey Lacker</a> threatened that if the acquisition did not go through, and later Bank of America were forced to request federal assistance, the management of Bank of America would be "gone". Other emails, read by Congressman <a href="/wiki/Dennis_Kucinich" title="Dennis Kucinich">Dennis Kucinich</a> during the course of Lewis' testimony, state that Mr. Lewis had foreseen the outrage from his shareholders that the purchase of Merrill would cause, and asked government regulators to issue a letter stating that the government had ordered him to complete the deal to acquire Merrill. Lewis, for his part, states he didn't recall requesting such a letter.
</p><p>The acquisition made Bank of America the number one <a href="/wiki/Securities_underwriting" class="mw-redirect" title="Securities underwriting">underwriter</a> of global <a href="/wiki/High-yield_debt" title="High-yield debt">high-yield debt</a>, the third largest underwriter of global equity and the ninth largest adviser on global mergers and acquisitions.<sup id="cite_ref-69" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-69"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>69<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> As the credit crisis eased, losses at Merrill Lynch subsided, and the subsidiary generated $3.7 billion of Bank of America's $4.2 billion in profit by the end of quarter one in 2009, and over 25% in quarter 3 2009.<sup id="cite_ref-70" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-70"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>70<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-BBergMLprofits_71-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BBergMLprofits-71"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>71<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>On September 28, 2012, Bank of America settled the class-action lawsuit over the Merrill Lynch acquisition and will pay $2.43 billion.<sup id="cite_ref-72" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-72"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>72<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> This was one of the first major securities class action lawsuits stemming from the <a href="/wiki/2008_financial_crisis" title="2008 financial crisis">2008 financial crisis</a> to settle. Many major financial institutions had a stake in this lawsuit, including <a href="/wiki/Chicago_Clearing_Corporation" title="Chicago Clearing Corporation">Chicago Clearing Corporation</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hedge_fund" title="Hedge fund">hedge funds</a>, and bank trusts, due to the belief that Bank of America stock was a sure investment.
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading4"><h4 id="Federal_Troubled_Asset_Relief_Program">Federal Troubled Asset Relief Program</h4><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Bank_of_America&action=edit&section=11" title="Edit section: Federal Troubled Asset Relief Program"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<p>On January 16, 2009, Bank of America received $20 billion and a guarantee of $118 billion in potential losses from the U.S. government through the <a href="/wiki/Troubled_Asset_Relief_Program" title="Troubled Asset Relief Program">Troubled Asset Relief Program</a> (TARP).<sup id="cite_ref-73" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-73"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>73<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> This was in addition to the $25 billion given to the bank in the fall of 2008 through TARP. The additional payment was part of a deal with the U.S. government to preserve Bank of America's merger with <a href="/wiki/Merrill_Lynch" class="mw-redirect" title="Merrill Lynch">Merrill Lynch</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-74" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-74"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>74<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Since then, members of the U.S. Congress have expressed considerable concern about how this money has been spent, especially since some of the recipients have been accused of misusing the bailout money.<sup id="cite_ref-75" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-75"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>75<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Then CEO <a href="/wiki/Ken_Lewis_(executive)" title="Ken Lewis (executive)">Ken Lewis</a> was quoted as claiming "We are still lending, and we are lending far more because of the TARP program." Members of the U.S. House of Representatives, however, were skeptical and quoted many anecdotes about loan applicants (particularly small business owners) being denied loans and credit card holders facing stiffer terms on the debt in their card accounts.
</p><p>According to an article in <i><a href="/wiki/The_New_York_Times" title="The New York Times">The New York Times</a></i> published on March 15, 2009, Bank of America received an additional $5.2 billion in government bailout money via the bailout of <a href="/wiki/American_International_Group" title="American International Group">American International Group</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-76" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-76"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>76<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>As a result of its federal bailout and management problems, <i><a href="/wiki/The_Wall_Street_Journal" title="The Wall Street Journal">The Wall Street Journal</a></i> reported that the Bank of America was operating under a secret "memorandum of understanding" (MOU) from the U.S. government that requires it to "overhaul its board and address perceived problems with risk and liquidity management". With the federal action, the institution has taken several steps, including arranging for six of its <a href="#Board_of_directors">directors</a> to resign and forming a Regulatory Impact Office. Bank of America faces several deadlines in July and August and if not met, could face harsher penalties by federal regulators. Bank of America did not respond to <i>The Wall Street Journal</i> story.<sup id="cite_ref-77" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-77"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>77<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>On December 2, 2009, Bank of America announced it would repay the entire $45 billion it received in TARP and exit the program, using $26.2 billion of excess liquidity along with $18.6 billion to be gained in "common equivalent securities" (<a href="/wiki/Tier_1_capital" title="Tier 1 capital">Tier 1 capital</a>). The bank announced it had completed the repayment on December 9. Bank of America's <a href="/wiki/Ken_Lewis_(executive)" title="Ken Lewis (executive)">Ken Lewis</a> said during the announcement, "We appreciate the critical role that the U.S. government played last fall in helping to stabilize financial markets, and we are pleased to be able to fully repay the investment, with interest.... As America's largest bank, we have a responsibility to make good on the taxpayers' investment, and our record shows that we have been able to fulfill that commitment while continuing to lend."<sup id="cite_ref-78" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-78"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>78<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-AFP_79-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-AFP-79"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>79<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading4"><h4 id="Bonus_settlement">Bonus settlement</h4><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Bank_of_America&action=edit&section=12" title="Edit section: Bonus settlement"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<p>On August 3, 2009, Bank of America agreed to pay a $33 million fine, without admission or denial of charges, to the <a href="/wiki/U.S._Securities_and_Exchange_Commission" title="U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission">U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission</a> (SEC) over the non-disclosure of an agreement to pay up to $5.8 billion of bonuses at Merrill. The bank approved the bonuses before the merger but did not disclose them to its shareholders when the shareholders were considering approving the Merrill acquisition, in December 2008. The issue was originally investigated by <a href="/wiki/New_York_Attorney_General" class="mw-redirect" title="New York Attorney General">New York Attorney General</a> <a href="/wiki/Andrew_Cuomo" title="Andrew Cuomo">Andrew Cuomo</a>, who commented after the suit and announced a settlement that "the timing of the bonuses, as well as the disclosures relating to them, constituted a 'surprising fit of corporate irresponsibility<span style="padding-right:.15em;">'</span>" and "our investigation of these and other matters pursuant to New York's <a href="/wiki/Martin_Act" title="Martin Act">Martin Act</a> will continue". Congressman Kucinich commented at the same time that "This may not be the last fine that Bank of America pays for how it handled its merger of Merrill Lynch."<sup id="cite_ref-80" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-80"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>80<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> A federal judge, <a href="/wiki/Jed_Rakoff" class="mw-redirect" title="Jed Rakoff">Jed Rakoff</a>, in an unusual action, refused to approve the settlement on August 5.<sup id="cite_ref-81" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-81"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>81<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
A first hearing before the judge on August 10 was at times heated, and he was "sharply critic[al]" of the bonuses. David Rosenfeld represented the SEC, and Lewis J. Liman, son of <a href="/wiki/Arthur_L._Liman" title="Arthur L. Liman">Arthur L. Liman</a>, represented the bank. The actual amount of bonuses paid was $3.6 billion, of which $850 million was "guaranteed" and the rest was shared among 39,000 workers who received average payments of $91,000; 696 people received more than $1 million in bonuses; at least one person received a more than $33 million bonus.<sup id="cite_ref-82" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-82"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>82<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>On September 14, the judge rejected the settlement and told the parties to prepare for trial to begin no later than February 1, 2010. The judge focused much of his criticism on the fact that the fine in the case would be paid by the bank's shareholders, who were the ones that were supposed to have been injured by the lack of disclosure. He wrote, "It is quite something else for the very management that is accused of having lied to its shareholders to determine how much of those victims' money should be used to make the case against the management go away," ... "The proposed settlement," the judge continued, "suggests a rather cynical relationship between the parties: the S.E.C. gets to claim that it is exposing wrongdoing on the part of the Bank of America in a high-profile merger; the bank's management gets to claim that they have been coerced into an onerous settlement by overzealous regulators. And all this is done at the expense, not only of the shareholders but also of the truth."<sup id="cite_ref-NYT10_83-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NYT10-83"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>83<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>While ultimately deferring to the SEC, in February 2010, Judge Rakoff approved a revised settlement with a $150 million fine "reluctantly", calling the accord "half-baked justice at best" and "inadequate and misguided". Addressing one of the concerns he raised in September, the fine will be "distributed only to Bank of America shareholders harmed by the non-disclosures, or 'legacy shareholders, an improvement on the prior $33 million while still "paltry", according to the judge. Case: SEC v. Bank of America Corp., 09-cv-06829, <a href="/wiki/United_States_District_Court_for_the_Southern_District_of_New_York" title="United States District Court for the Southern District of New York">United States District Court for the Southern District of New York</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-84" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-84"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>84<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Investigations also were held on this issue in the <a href="/wiki/United_States_House_Committee_on_Oversight_and_Government_Reform" title="United States House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform">United States House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-NYT10_83-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NYT10-83"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>83<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> under chairman <a href="/wiki/Edolphus_Towns" title="Edolphus Towns">Edolphus Towns</a> (D-NY)<sup id="cite_ref-85" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-85"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>85<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> and in its investigative <a href="/wiki/United_States_House_Oversight_and_Government_Reform_Subcommittee_on_Domestic_Policy" title="United States House Oversight and Government Reform Subcommittee on Domestic Policy">Domestic Policy Subcommittee</a> under Kucinich.<sup id="cite_ref-86" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-86"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>86<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading4"><h4 id="Fraud">Fraud</h4><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Bank_of_America&action=edit&section=13" title="Edit section: Fraud"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<p>In 2010, the U.S. government accused the bank of defrauding schools, hospitals, and dozens of state and local government organizations via misconduct and illegal activities involving the investment of proceeds from municipal bond sales. As a result, the bank agreed to pay $137.7 million, including $25 million to the Internal Revenue Service and $4.5 million to the state attorney general, to the affected organizations to settle the allegations.<sup id="cite_ref-87" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-87"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>87<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Former bank official Douglas Campbell pleaded guilty to antitrust, conspiracy, and wire fraud charges. As of January 2011<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Bank_of_America&action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, other bankers and brokers are under indictment or investigation.<sup id="cite_ref-88" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-88"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>88<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>On October 24, 2012, the top <a href="/wiki/Federal_prosecutor" class="mw-redirect" title="Federal prosecutor">federal prosecutor</a> in <a href="/wiki/Manhattan" title="Manhattan">Manhattan</a> filed a <a href="/wiki/Lawsuit" title="Lawsuit">lawsuit</a> alleging that Bank of America fraudulently cost American taxpayers more than $1 billion when Countrywide Financial sold toxic mortgages to <a href="/wiki/Fannie_Mae" title="Fannie Mae">Fannie Mae</a> and <a href="/wiki/Freddie_Mac" title="Freddie Mac">Freddie Mac</a>. The scheme was called 'Hustle', or High Speed Swim Lane.<sup id="cite_ref-89" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-89"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>89<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-NYTimes_hustle_90-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NYTimes_hustle-90"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>90<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> On May 23, 2016, the Second U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals ruled that the finding of fact by the jury that low quality mortgages were supplied by Countrywide to Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac in the "Hustle" case supported only "intentional breach of contract", not a fraud. The action, for civil fraud, relied on provisions of the <a href="/wiki/Financial_Institutions_Reform,_Recovery,_and_Enforcement_Act_of_1989#Use_with_respect_to_the_subprime_mortgage_crisis" title="Financial Institutions Reform, Recovery, and Enforcement Act of 1989">Financial Institutions Reform, Recovery and Enforcement Act</a>. The decision turned on lack of intent to defraud at the time the contract to supply mortgages was made.<sup id="cite_ref-WSJ52316_91-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-WSJ52316-91"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>91<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading4"><h4 id="Change_of_CEO">Change of CEO</h4><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Bank_of_America&action=edit&section=14" title="Edit section: Change of CEO"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<p>Ken Lewis, who had lost the title of chairman of the board, announced that he would retire as CEO effective December 31, 2009, in part due to controversy and legal investigations concerning the purchase of Merrill Lynch. <a href="/wiki/Brian_Moynihan" title="Brian Moynihan">Brian Moynihan</a> became president and CEO effective January 1, 2010, and afterward credit card charge offs and delinquencies declined in January. Bank of America also repaid the $45 billion it had received from the Troubled Assets Relief Program.<sup id="cite_ref-92" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-92"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>92<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-93" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-93"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>93<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="2011_to_present">2011 to present</h3><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Bank_of_America&action=edit&section=15" title="Edit section: 2011 to present"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading4"><h4 id="Downsizing_(2011_to_2014)"><span id="Downsizing_.282011_to_2014.29"></span>Downsizing (2011 to 2014)</h4><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Bank_of_America&action=edit&section=16" title="Edit section: Downsizing (2011 to 2014)"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<p>During 2011, Bank of America began conducting personnel reductions of an estimated 36,000 people, contributing to intended savings of $5 billion per year by 2014.<sup id="cite_ref-94" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-94"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>94<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> In December 2011, <i>Forbes</i> ranked Bank of America's financial wealth 91st out of the nation's largest 100 banks and thrift institutions.<sup id="cite_ref-95" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-95"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>95<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Bank of America cut around 16,000 jobs in a quicker fashion by the end of 2012 as revenue continued to decline because of new regulations and a slow economy. This put a plan one year ahead of time to eliminate 30,000 jobs under a cost-cutting program, called Project New BAC.<sup id="cite_ref-96" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-96"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>96<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> In the first quarter of 2014, <a href="/wiki/Berkshire_Hathaway" title="Berkshire Hathaway">Berkshire</a> bank purchased 20 Bank of America branches in Central and eastern New York for 14.4 million dollars. The branches were from Utica/Rome region and down the Mohawk Valley east to the capital region. In April and May 2014, Bank of America sold two dozen branches in Michigan to <a href="/wiki/Huntington_Bancshares" title="Huntington Bancshares">Huntington Bancshares</a>. The locations were converted to Huntington National Bank branches in September.<sup id="cite_ref-97" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-97"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>97<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>As part of its new strategy Bank of America is focused on growing its mobile banking platform. As of 2014<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Bank_of_America&action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, Bank of America has 31 million active online users and 16 million mobile users. Its retail banking branches have decreased to 4,900 as a result of increased mobile banking use and a decline in customer branch visits. By 2018, the number of mobile users has increased to 25.3 million and the number of locations fell to 4,411 at the end of June.<sup id="cite_ref-98" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-98"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>98<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading4"><h4 id="Sale_of_stake_in_China_Construction_Bank">Sale of stake in China Construction Bank</h4><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Bank_of_America&action=edit&section=17" title="Edit section: Sale of stake in China Construction Bank"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<p>In 2005, Bank of America acquired a 9% stake in <a href="/wiki/China_Construction_Bank" title="China Construction Bank">China Construction Bank</a>, one of the <a href="/wiki/Big_Four_(banking)#China" title="Big Four (banking)">Big Four banks in China</a>, for US$3 billion.<sup id="cite_ref-99" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-99"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>99<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> It represented the company's largest foray into China's growing banking sector. Bank of America has offices in Hong Kong, Shanghai, and <a href="/wiki/Guangzhou" title="Guangzhou">Guangzhou</a> and was looking to greatly expand its Chinese business as a result of this deal. In 2008, Bank of America was awarded Project Finance Deal of the Year at the 2008 ALB Hong Kong Law Awards.<sup id="cite_ref-100" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-100"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>100<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> In November 2011, Bank of America announced plans to divest most of its stake in the China Construction Bank.<sup id="cite_ref-101" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-101"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>101<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>In September 2013, Bank of America sold its remaining stake in the <a href="/wiki/China_Construction_Bank" title="China Construction Bank">China Construction Bank</a> for as much as $1.5 billion, marking the firm's full exit from the country.<sup id="cite_ref-102" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-102"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>102<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading4"><h4 id="$17_billion_settlement_with_Justice_Department"><span id=".2417_billion_settlement_with_Justice_Department"></span>$17 billion settlement with Justice Department</h4><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Bank_of_America&action=edit&section=18" title="Edit section: $17 billion settlement with Justice Department"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<p>In August 2014, Bank of America agreed to a near$17 billion deal to settle claims against it relating to the sale of toxic mortgage-linked securities including subprime home loans, in what was believed to be the largest settlement in U.S. corporate history. The bank agreed with the <a href="/wiki/United_States_Department_of_Justice" title="United States Department of Justice">U.S. Justice Department</a> to pay $9.65 billion in fines, and $7 billion in relief to the victims of the faulty loans which included homeowners, borrowers, pension funds and municipalities.<sup id="cite_ref-BAsettlement_103-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BAsettlement-103"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>103<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Real estate economist <a href="/wiki/Jed_Kolko" title="Jed Kolko">Jed Kolko</a> said the settlement is a "drop in the bucket" compared to the $700 billion in damages done to 11 million homeowners. Since the settlement covered such a substantial portion of the market, he said for most consumers "you're out of luck".<sup id="cite_ref-104" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-104"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>104<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Much of the government's prosecution was based on information provided by three whistleblowers  Shareef Abdou (a senior vice president at the bank), Robert Madsen (a professional appraiser employed by a bank subsidiary), and Edward O'Donnell (a Fannie Mae official). The three men received $170 million in whistleblower awards.<sup id="cite_ref-105" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-105"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>105<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading4"><h4 id="DOD_Community_Bank">DOD Community Bank</h4><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Bank_of_America&action=edit&section=19" title="Edit section: DOD Community Bank"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:DOD_Community_Bank_operated_by_Bank_of_America_logo.png" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/4/46/DOD_Community_Bank_operated_by_Bank_of_America_logo.png" decoding="async" width="180" height="40" class="mw-file-element" data-file-width="180" data-file-height="40"></a><figcaption>DOD Community Bank's logo</figcaption></figure>
<p>Bank of America has formed a partnership with the <a href="/wiki/United_States_Department_of_Defense" title="United States Department of Defense">United States Department of Defense</a> creating a newly chartered bank <b>DOD Community Bank</b><sup id="cite_ref-106" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-106"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>106<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> ("Community Bank") providing full banking services to military personnel at 68 branches and ATM locations<sup id="cite_ref-107" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-107"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>107<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> on U.S. military installations in <a href="/wiki/Guantanamo_Bay_Naval_Base" title="Guantanamo Bay Naval Base">Guantanamo Bay Naval Base</a> <a href="/wiki/Cuba" title="Cuba">Cuba</a>, <a href="/wiki/Diego_Garcia" title="Diego Garcia">Diego Garcia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Germany" title="Germany">Germany</a>, <a href="/wiki/Japan" title="Japan">Japan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Italy" title="Italy">Italy</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kwajalein_Atoll" title="Kwajalein Atoll">Kwajalein Atoll</a>, <a href="/wiki/South_Korea" title="South Korea">South Korea</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Netherlands" title="Netherlands">Netherlands</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/United_Kingdom" title="United Kingdom">United Kingdom</a>. Even though Bank of America operates Community Bank, customer services are not interchangeable between the two financial institutions,<sup id="cite_ref-108" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-108"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>108<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> meaning that a Community Bank customer cannot go to a Bank of America branch and withdraw from their account and vice versa. Deposits made into checking and savings accounts are insured by the <a href="/wiki/Federal_Deposit_Insurance_Corporation" title="Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation">Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation</a> up to $250,000 despite the fact that none of Community's operating branches are located within the jurisdictional borders of the United States.
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading4"><h4 id="Decision_not_to_finance_makers_of_military-style_guns">Decision not to finance makers of military-style guns</h4><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Bank_of_America&action=edit&section=20" title="Edit section: Decision not to finance makers of military-style guns"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<p>In April 2018, Bank of America announced that it would stop providing financing to makers of military-style weapons such as the <a href="/wiki/AR-15_style_rifle" class="mw-redirect" title="AR-15 style rifle">AR-15</a> rifle.<sup id="cite_ref-109" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-109"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>109<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> In announcing the decision, Bank of America referenced recent mass shootings and said that it wanted to "contribute in any way we can" to reduce them.
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading4"><h4 id="Return_to_expansion_(2015present)"><span id="Return_to_expansion_.282015.E2.80.93present.29"></span>Return to expansion (2015present)</h4><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Bank_of_America&action=edit&section=21" title="Edit section: Return to expansion (2015present)"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Bank_of_America_footprint.png" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/15/Bank_of_America_footprint.png/250px-Bank_of_America_footprint.png" decoding="async" width="250" height="130" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/15/Bank_of_America_footprint.png/500px-Bank_of_America_footprint.png 1.5x" data-file-width="6000" data-file-height="3126"></a><figcaption>Bank of America's footprint in 2015, prior to its organic expansion in the <a href="/wiki/Denver" title="Denver">Denver</a>, <a href="/wiki/Indianapolis" title="Indianapolis">Indianapolis</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ohio" title="Ohio">Ohio</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pittsburgh" title="Pittsburgh">Pittsburgh</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Twin_Cities" class="mw-redirect" title="Twin Cities">Twin Cities</a> markets</figcaption></figure>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:A_Bank_of_America_branch_in_Chestnut_Hill,_Philadelphia.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/87/A_Bank_of_America_branch_in_Chestnut_Hill%2C_Philadelphia.jpg/250px-A_Bank_of_America_branch_in_Chestnut_Hill%2C_Philadelphia.jpg" decoding="async" width="250" height="333" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/87/A_Bank_of_America_branch_in_Chestnut_Hill%2C_Philadelphia.jpg/500px-A_Bank_of_America_branch_in_Chestnut_Hill%2C_Philadelphia.jpg 1.5x" data-file-width="2912" data-file-height="3883"></a><figcaption>A Bank of America branch in <a href="/wiki/Chestnut_Hill,_Philadelphia" title="Chestnut Hill, Philadelphia">Chestnut Hill</a> section of <a href="/wiki/Philadelphia" title="Philadelphia">Philadelphia</a></figcaption></figure>
<p>In 2015, Bank of America began expanding organically, opening branches in cities where it previously did not have a retail presence. They started that year in <a href="/wiki/Denver" title="Denver">Denver</a>, followed by <a href="/wiki/Minneapolis%E2%80%93Saint_Paul" title="MinneapolisSaint Paul">MinneapolisSaint Paul</a> and <a href="/wiki/Indianapolis" title="Indianapolis">Indianapolis</a>, in all cases having at least one of its <a href="/wiki/Big_Four_(banking)#United_States" title="Big Four (banking)">Big Four</a> competitors, with <a href="/wiki/Chase_Bank" title="Chase Bank">Chase Bank</a> being available in Denver and Indianapolis, while <a href="/wiki/Wells_Fargo" title="Wells Fargo">Wells Fargo</a> is available in Denver and the Twin Cities.<sup id="cite_ref-Pittsburgh_110-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Pittsburgh-110"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>110<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The Twin Cities market is also the home market of <a href="/wiki/U.S._Bancorp" title="U.S. Bancorp">U.S. Bancorp</a>, the largest non-Big Four rival.
</p><p>In January 2018, Bank of America announced an organic expansion of its retail footprint into <a href="/wiki/Pittsburgh" title="Pittsburgh">Pittsburgh</a> and surrounding areas, to supplement its existing commercial lending and investment businesses in the area. Before the expansion, Pittsburgh had been one of the largest US cities without a retail presence by any of the Big Four, with locally based <a href="/wiki/PNC_Financial_Services" title="PNC Financial Services">PNC Financial Services</a> (no. 6 nationally) having a commanding market share in the area;<sup id="cite_ref-Pittsburgh_110-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Pittsburgh-110"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>110<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-111" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-111"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>111<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> this coincided with Chase making a similar expansion into Pittsburgh.<sup id="cite_ref-112" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-112"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>112<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> By the end of the fiscal year 2020, Bank of America had become Pittsburgh's 16th largest bank by deposits, which considering the dominance of PNC and <a href="/wiki/BNY_Mellon" class="mw-redirect" title="BNY Mellon">BNY Mellon</a> in the market is considered relatively impressive.<sup id="cite_ref-113" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-113"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>113<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> By 2021, Bank of America had moved up to 12th in the market.<sup id="cite_ref-Summary_of_Deposits_-_Market_Share_114-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Summary_of_Deposits_-_Market_Share-114"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>114<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>In February 2018, Bank of America announced it would expand into Ohio across the state's three biggest cities (<a href="/wiki/Cleveland" title="Cleveland">Cleveland</a>, <a href="/wiki/Columbus,_Ohio" title="Columbus, Ohio">Columbus</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Cincinnati" title="Cincinnati">Cincinnati</a>), which are strongholds of Chase.<sup id="cite_ref-115" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-115"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>115<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-116" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-116"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>116<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Columbus serves as the bank's hub in Ohio due to its central location as the state's capital, its overall size and growth, and an existing Bank of America call center for its credit card division in suburban <a href="/wiki/Westerville,_Ohio" title="Westerville, Ohio">Westerville</a>. Within a year of entering Ohio, Columbus quickly saw the bank become the 5th largest in the market by deposits, behind only banks either based in Ohio (<a href="/wiki/Fifth_Third_Bank" title="Fifth Third Bank">Fifth Third Bank</a> and locally based <a href="/wiki/Huntington_Bancshares" title="Huntington Bancshares">Huntington Bancshares</a>) or have a major presence as a result of an acquisition of an Ohio-based institution (Chase and PNC), and ahead of US Bancorp (also with a large presence due to acquiring an Ohio-based bank), Ohio-based <a href="/wiki/KeyBank" title="KeyBank">KeyBank</a>, and several local institutions.<sup id="cite_ref-117" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-117"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>117<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> As of 2021, Bank of America is the 9th largest bank by deposits in all of Ohio.<sup id="cite_ref-Summary_of_Deposits_-_Market_Share_114-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Summary_of_Deposits_-_Market_Share-114"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>114<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>In January 2020, Bank of America hired new advisors whose primary functions are to assist ultra-wealthy clients.<sup id="cite_ref-118" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-118"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>118<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading2"><h2 id="Operations">Operations</h2><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Bank_of_America&action=edit&section=22" title="Edit section: Operations"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<p>Bank of America generates 90% of its revenues in its domestic market. The core of Bank of America's strategy is to be the number one bank in its domestic market. It has achieved this through key acquisitions.<sup id="cite_ref-119" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-119"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>119<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Consumer_Banking">Consumer Banking</h3><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Bank_of_America&action=edit&section=23" title="Edit section: Consumer Banking"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Bank_of_America_-_Near_Northeast.JPG" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e0/Bank_of_America_-_Near_Northeast.JPG/250px-Bank_of_America_-_Near_Northeast.JPG" decoding="async" width="250" height="158" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e0/Bank_of_America_-_Near_Northeast.JPG/500px-Bank_of_America_-_Near_Northeast.JPG 1.5x" data-file-width="3255" data-file-height="2059"></a><figcaption>A Bank of America branch in <a href="/wiki/Washington,_D.C." title="Washington, D.C.">Washington, D.C.</a></figcaption></figure>
<p>Consumer Banking, the largest division in the company, provides financial services to consumers and small businesses including, banking, investments, merchant services, and lending products including business loans, mortgages, and credit cards. It provides <a href="/wiki/Stockbroker" title="Stockbroker">stockbroker</a> services via <a href="/wiki/Merrill_Edge" title="Merrill Edge">Merrill Edge</a>, a specific <a href="/wiki/Division_(business)" title="Division (business)">division</a> for investment and related services, such as research and call center counsel, after Merrill Lynch became a subsidiary of Bank of America. The consumer banking division represented 38% of the company's total revenue in 2016.<sup id="cite_ref-10K-2016_120-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-10K-2016-120"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>120<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The company earns revenue from interest income, service charges, and fees. In addition, the company is a <a href="/wiki/Mortgage_servicer" title="Mortgage servicer">mortgage servicer</a>. It competes primarily with the <a href="/wiki/Retail_banking" title="Retail banking">retail banking</a> arms of America's three other megabanks: <a href="/wiki/Citigroup" title="Citigroup">Citigroup</a>, <a href="/wiki/JPMorgan_Chase" title="JPMorgan Chase">JPMorgan Chase</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Wells_Fargo" title="Wells Fargo">Wells Fargo</a>. The Consumer Banking organization includes over 4,600 retail financial centers and approximately 15,900 <a href="/wiki/Automated_teller_machine" class="mw-redirect" title="Automated teller machine">automated teller machines</a>.
</p><p>Bank of America is a member of the <a href="/wiki/Global_ATM_Alliance" title="Global ATM Alliance">Global ATM Alliance</a>, a joint venture of several major international banks that provides for reduced fees for consumers using their <a href="/wiki/Automated_teller_machine" class="mw-redirect" title="Automated teller machine">ATM</a> card or <a href="/wiki/Debit_card" title="Debit card">check card</a> at another bank within the Global ATM Alliance when travelling internationally. This feature is restricted to withdrawals using a debit card and users are still subject to foreign currency conversion fees, credit card withdrawals are still subject to cash advance fees and foreign currency conversion fees.
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Global_Banking">Global Banking</h3><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Bank_of_America&action=edit&section=24" title="Edit section: Global Banking"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:LaurastBOAT.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/da/LaurastBOAT.jpg/250px-LaurastBOAT.jpg" decoding="async" width="250" height="333" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/da/LaurastBOAT.jpg/500px-LaurastBOAT.jpg 1.5x" data-file-width="1895" data-file-height="2526"></a><figcaption><a href="/wiki/Bank_of_America_Tower_(Jacksonville)" title="Bank of America Tower (Jacksonville)">Bank of America Tower</a>, on <a href="/wiki/Laura_Street" title="Laura Street">Laura Street</a> in <a href="/wiki/Jacksonville,_Florida" title="Jacksonville, Florida">Jacksonville, Florida</a></figcaption></figure>
<p>The Global Banking division provides banking services, including investment banking and lending products to businesses. It includes the businesses of Global Corporate Banking, Global Commercial Banking, Business Banking, and Global Investment Banking. The division represented 22% of the company's revenue in 2016.<sup id="cite_ref-10K-2016_120-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-10K-2016-120"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>120<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Before Bank of America's acquisition of <a href="/wiki/Merrill_Lynch" class="mw-redirect" title="Merrill Lynch">Merrill Lynch</a>, the Global Corporate and Investment Banking (GCIB) business operated as <a href="/wiki/Banc_of_America_Securities_(1998%E2%80%932008)" class="mw-redirect" title="Banc of America Securities (19982008)">Banc of America Securities</a> LLC. The bank's investment banking activities operate under the Merrill Lynch subsidiary and provided <a href="/wiki/Mergers_and_acquisitions" title="Mergers and acquisitions">mergers and acquisitions</a> advisory, <a href="/wiki/Underwriting" title="Underwriting">underwriting</a>, capital markets, as well as sales & trading in fixed income and equities markets. Its strongest groups include <a href="/wiki/Leverage_(finance)" title="Leverage (finance)">Leveraged Finance</a>, <a href="/wiki/Syndicated_Loans" class="mw-redirect" title="Syndicated Loans">Syndicated Loans</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Mortgage-backed_security" title="Mortgage-backed security">mortgage-backed securities</a>. It also has one of the largest research teams on <a href="/wiki/Wall_Street" title="Wall Street">Wall Street</a>. <a href="/wiki/Bank_of_America_Merrill_Lynch" class="mw-redirect" title="Bank of America Merrill Lynch">Bank of America Merrill Lynch</a> is headquartered in New York City.
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Global_Wealth_and_Investment_Management">Global Wealth and Investment Management</h3><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Bank_of_America&action=edit&section=25" title="Edit section: Global Wealth and Investment Management"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<p>The Global Wealth and Investment Management (GWIM) division manages the investment assets of institutions and individuals. It includes the businesses of Merrill Lynch Global Wealth Management and U.S. Trust and represented 21% of the company's total revenue in 2016.<sup id="cite_ref-10K-2016_120-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-10K-2016-120"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>120<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> It is among the 10 largest U.S. wealth managers. It has over $2.5 trillion in client balances.<sup id="cite_ref-10K-2016_120-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-10K-2016-120"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>120<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> GWIM has five primary lines of business: Premier Banking & Investments (including Bank of America Investment Services, Inc.), The Private Bank, Family Wealth Advisors, and Bank of America Specialist.
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Global_Markets">Global Markets</h3><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Bank_of_America&action=edit&section=26" title="Edit section: Global Markets"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:The_Chairman_and_CEO,_Bank_of_America,_Mr._Brian_Moynihan_meeting_the_Prime_Minister,_Shri_Narendra_Modi,_in_New_Delhi_on_December_03,_2014.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img alt="International relations" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/07/The_Chairman_and_CEO%2C_Bank_of_America%2C_Mr._Brian_Moynihan_meeting_the_Prime_Minister%2C_Shri_Narendra_Modi%2C_in_New_Delhi_on_December_03%2C_2014.jpg/250px-The_Chairman_and_CEO%2C_Bank_of_America%2C_Mr._Brian_Moynihan_meeting_the_Prime_Minister%2C_Shri_Narendra_Modi%2C_in_New_Delhi_on_December_03%2C_2014.jpg" decoding="async" width="250" height="101" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/07/The_Chairman_and_CEO%2C_Bank_of_America%2C_Mr._Brian_Moynihan_meeting_the_Prime_Minister%2C_Shri_Narendra_Modi%2C_in_New_Delhi_on_December_03%2C_2014.jpg/500px-The_Chairman_and_CEO%2C_Bank_of_America%2C_Mr._Brian_Moynihan_meeting_the_Prime_Minister%2C_Shri_Narendra_Modi%2C_in_New_Delhi_on_December_03%2C_2014.jpg 1.5x" data-file-width="2180" data-file-height="878"></a><figcaption>Bank of America CEO <a href="/wiki/Brian_Moynihan" title="Brian Moynihan">Brian Moynihan</a> meeting <a href="/wiki/Narendra_Modi" title="Narendra Modi">Narendra Modi</a>, <a href="/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_India" title="Prime Minister of India">Prime Minister of India</a>, in <a href="/wiki/New_Delhi" title="New Delhi">New Delhi</a>, in December 2014</figcaption></figure>
<p>The Global Markets division offers services to institutional clients, including trading in <a href="/wiki/Financial_securities" class="mw-redirect" title="Financial securities">financial securities</a>. The division provides research and other services such as securities service, <a href="/wiki/Market_maker" title="Market maker">market maker</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Risk_management" title="Risk management">risk management</a> using <a href="/wiki/Derivative_(finance)" title="Derivative (finance)">derivatives</a>. The division represented 19% of the company's total revenues in 2016.<sup id="cite_ref-10K-2016_120-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-10K-2016-120"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>120<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Labor">Labor</h3><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Bank_of_America&action=edit&section=27" title="Edit section: Labor"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<p>On April 9, 2019, the company announced minimum wage will be increased beginning May 1, 2019, to $17.00 an hour until it reaches a goal of $20.00 an hour in 2021.<sup id="cite_ref-121" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-121"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>121<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Offices">Offices</h3><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Bank_of_America&action=edit&section=28" title="Edit section: Offices"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<p>The Bank of America principal executive offices are located in the Bank of America Corporate Center, Charlotte, North Carolina. The skyscraper is located at 100 North Tryon Street, and stands at 871 ft (265 m), having been completed in 1992.
</p><p>In 2012, Bank of America cut ties to the <a href="/wiki/American_Legislative_Exchange_Council" title="American Legislative Exchange Council">American Legislative Exchange Council</a> (ALEC).<sup id="cite_ref-122" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-122"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>122<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading4"><h4 id="International_offices">International offices</h4><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Bank_of_America&action=edit&section=29" title="Edit section: International offices"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<p>Bank of America's Global Corporate and Investment Banking has its U.S. headquarters in Charlotte, European headquarters in Dublin, and Asian headquarters in Hong Kong and Singapore.<sup id="cite_ref-123" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-123"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>123<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
