**Footnotes / references**[[1]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America#cite_note-10K-2024-1)[[2]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America#cite_note-2)  
The **Bank of America Corporation** (**Bank of America**) (often abbreviated **BofA** or **BoA**) is an American multinational [investment bank](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Investment_banking "Investment banking") and [financial services](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Financial_services "Financial services") [holding company](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Holding_company "Holding company") headquartered at the [Bank of America Corporate Center](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America_Corporate_Center "Bank of America Corporate Center") in [Charlotte, North Carolina](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Charlotte,_North_Carolina "Charlotte, North Carolina"), with [investment banking](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Investment_bank "Investment bank") and auxiliary headquarters in [Manhattan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Manhattan "Manhattan"). The bank was founded by the merger of [NationsBank](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NationsBank "NationsBank") and [Bank of America](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America_\(1904%E2%80%931998\) "Bank of America \(19041998\)") in 1998. It is the [second-largest banking institution](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_largest_banks_in_the_United_States "List of largest banks in the United States") in the United States and the second-largest bank in the world by [market capitalization](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Market_capitalization "Market capitalization"), both after [JPMorgan Chase](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/JPMorgan_Chase "JPMorgan Chase"). Bank of America is one of the [Big Four](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Big_Four_\(banking\)#United_States "Big Four \(banking\)") banking institutions of the United States.[[3]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America#cite_note-3) and one of eight [systemically important financial institutions](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Systemically_important_financial_institution "Systemically important financial institution") in the US. It serves about 10 percent of all American bank deposits, in direct competition with JPMorgan Chase, [Citigroup](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citigroup "Citigroup"), and [Wells Fargo](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wells_Fargo "Wells Fargo"). Its primary financial services revolve around [commercial banking](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Commercial_bank "Commercial bank"), [wealth management](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wealth_management "Wealth management"), and investment banking. Through mergers, the oldest branch of the Bank of America franchise can be traced to 1784, when [Massachusetts Bank](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/BankBoston#The_Massachusetts_Bank "BankBoston") was chartered, the first federally chartered joint-stock owned bank in the United States. Another branch of its history goes back to the U.S.-based [Bank of Italy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_Italy_\(United_States\) "Bank of Italy \(United States\)"), founded by [Amadeo Pietro Giannini](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amadeo_Giannini "Amadeo Giannini") in 1904, which provided various banking options to [Italian immigrants](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Italian_diaspora "Italian diaspora") who [faced service discrimination](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anti-Italianism "Anti-Italianism").[[4]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America#cite_note-PBSGiannini-4) Headquartered in [San Francisco, California](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/San_Francisco "San Francisco"), Giannini acquired [Banca d'America e d'Italia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Banca_d%27America_e_d%27Italia "Banca d'America e d'Italia"), in 1922 and eventually did business as Bank of America. 
In the 1950s, passage of landmark federal banking legislation facilitated rapid growth, quickly establishing prominent shares for the present bank's predecessors. After suffering significant losses during the [1998 Russian financial crisis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1998_Russian_financial_crisis "1998 Russian financial crisis"), BankAmerica, as it was then known, was acquired by the Charlotte-based [NationsBank](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NationsBank "NationsBank") for $62 billion. Following what was then the [largest bank acquisition in history](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_largest_mergers_and_acquisitions "List of largest mergers and acquisitions"), the Bank of America Corporation was founded. Through a series of mergers and acquisitions, it built upon its commercial banking business by establishing [Merrill Lynch](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Merrill_Lynch "Merrill Lynch") for wealth management and [Bank of America Merrill Lynch](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America_Merrill_Lynch "Bank of America Merrill Lynch") for investment banking in 2008 and 2009, respectively, and since renamed BofA Securities.[[5]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America#cite_note-ATLoffer-5)
Both Bank of America and Merrill Lynch Wealth Management retain large market shares in their respective offerings. The [investment bank](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Investment_banking "Investment banking") is considered within the "[Bulge Bracket](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bulge_Bracket "Bulge Bracket")" as the [third largest investment bank in the world](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_investment_banks "List of investment banks"), as of 2018[[update]](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Bank_of_America&action=edit).[[6]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America#cite_note-6) Its wealth management unit manages $1.08 trillion in [assets under management](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Assets_under_management "Assets under management") (AUM) as the [second largest wealth manager in the world](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Private_banking#Private_banking_rankings "Private banking"), after [UBS](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/UBS "UBS").[[7]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America#cite_note-7) In commercial banking, Bank of America has operations, but does not necessarily maintain retail branches in all 50 states of the United States, [Washington, D.C.](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Washington,_D.C. "Washington, D.C."), and over 40 other countries.[[8]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America#cite_note-8) Its commercial banking footprint encapsulates 46 million consumer and small business relationships at 4,600 banking centers and 16,000 [automated teller machines](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Automated_teller_machine "Automated teller machine") (ATMs). 
The bank's large market share, business activities, and economic impact has led to numerous lawsuits and investigations regarding both mortgages and financial disclosures dating back to the [2008 financial crisis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2008_financial_crisis "2008 financial crisis"). Its corporate practices of servicing the [middle class](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Middle_class "Middle class") and wider banking community have yielded a substantial market share since the early 20th century. As of August 2018[[update]](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Bank_of_America&action=edit), Bank of America has a $313.5 billion [market capitalization](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Market_capitalization "Market capitalization"), making it the [13th largest company in the world](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_public_corporations_by_market_capitalization "List of public corporations by market capitalization"). As the sixth largest American public company, it garnered $102.98 billion in sales as of June 2018[[update]](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Bank_of_America&action=edit).[[9]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America#cite_note-9) Bank of America was ranked No. 25 on the 2020 [Fortune 500](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fortune_500 "Fortune 500") rankings of the largest US corporations by total revenue.[[10]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America#cite_note-10) Likewise, Bank of America was also ranked No. 6 on the 2023 Global 2000 rankings done by Forbes.[[11]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America#cite_note-11) Bank of America was named the "World's Best Bank" by the _[Euromoney Institutional Investor](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Euromoney_Institutional_Investor "Euromoney Institutional Investor")_ in its 2018 Awards for Excellence.[[12]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America#cite_note-12)[[13]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America#cite_note-13)
## History
[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Bank_of_America&action=edit&section=1 "Edit section: History")]
[Bank of America, Los Angeles](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America,_Los_Angeles "Bank of America, Los Angeles") was founded in California in 1923. In 1928, this entity was acquired by [Bank of Italy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_Italy_\(United_States\) "Bank of Italy \(United States\)") of San Francisco, which took the Bank of America name two years later.[[14]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America#cite_note-britannica.com-14)
The eastern portion of the Bank of America franchise can be traced to 1784, when [Massachusetts Bank](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/BankBoston#The_Massachusetts_Bank "BankBoston") was chartered, the first federally chartered joint-stock owned bank in the United States and only the second bank to receive a charter in the United States. This bank became [FleetBoston](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/FleetBoston_Financial "FleetBoston Financial"), with which Bank of America merged in 2004. In 1874, [Commercial National Bank](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Commercial_National_Bank "Commercial National Bank") was founded in Charlotte. That bank merged with American Trust Company in 1958 to form American Commercial Bank.[[15]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America#cite_note-15) Two years later it became [North Carolina National Bank](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/North_Carolina_National_Bank "North Carolina National Bank") when it merged with Security National Bank of Greensboro. In 1991, it merged with [C&S](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizens_%26_Southern_National_Bank "Citizens & Southern National Bank")/[Sovran](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sovran_Bank "Sovran Bank") Corporation of [Atlanta](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Atlanta "Atlanta") and [Norfolk](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Norfolk,_Virginia "Norfolk, Virginia") to form [NationsBank](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NationsBank "NationsBank"). 
The central portion of the franchise dates to 1910, when Commercial National Bank and Continental National Bank of Chicago merged in 1910 to form Continental & Commercial National Bank, which evolved into [Continental Illinois National Bank & Trust](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Continental_Illinois "Continental Illinois"). 
### Bank of America
[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Bank_of_America&action=edit&section=2 "Edit section: Bank of America")]
Main article: [Bank of Italy (United States)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_Italy_\(United_States\) "Bank of Italy \(United States\)")
[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ea/M._A._P._Giannini%2C_pr%C3%A9sident_de_la_Banque_d%27Italie.jpg/250px-M._A._P._Giannini%2C_pr%C3%A9sident_de_la_Banque_d%27Italie.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:M._A._P._Giannini,_pr%C3%A9sident_de_la_Banque_d%27Italie.jpg)[Amadeo Giannini](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amadeo_Giannini "Amadeo Giannini"), founder of [Bank of Italy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_Italy_\(United_States\) "Bank of Italy \(United States\)"), in 1927
The history of Bank of America dates back to October 17, 1904, when [Amadeo Pietro Giannini](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amadeo_Giannini "Amadeo Giannini") (18701949) founded the [Bank of Italy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_Italy_\(United_States\) "Bank of Italy \(United States\)"), in San Francisco.[[14]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America#cite_note-britannica.com-14) In 1922, Bank of America, Los Angeles was established with Giannini as a minority investor. The two banks merged in 1928 and consolidated with other bank holdings to create what would become the largest banking institution in the country.[[16]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America#cite_note-:0-16)
In 1918, another corporation, Bancitaly Corporation, was organized by A. P. Giannini, the largest stockholder of which was Stockholders Auxiliary Corporation.[_[citation needed](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] This company acquired the stocks of various banks located in New York City and certain foreign countries.[_[citation needed](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]
In 1928, Giannini merged his bank with [Bank of America, Los Angeles](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America,_Los_Angeles "Bank of America, Los Angeles"), headed by [Orra E. Monnette](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Orra_E._Monnette "Orra E. Monnette"). Bank of Italy was renamed on November 3, 1930, to [Bank of America National Trust and Savings Association](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America_NT%26SA "Bank of America NT&SA"),[[17]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America#cite_note-17) which was the only such designated bank in the United States at that time. Giannini and Monnette headed the resulting company, serving as co-chairs.[[18]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America#cite_note-18)
### Expansion in California
[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Bank_of_America&action=edit&section=3 "Edit section: Expansion in California")]
[![Early Bank of America building](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/The_Bank_of_America_8d28756v.jpg/250px-The_Bank_of_America_8d28756v.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:The_Bank_of_America_8d28756v.jpg)Entrance to Bank of America in [San Francisco](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/San_Francisco "San Francisco") in 1943
Giannini introduced branch banking shortly after 1909 legislation in California allowed for branch banking in the state, establishing the bank's first branch outside San Francisco in 1909 in San Jose. By 1929 the bank had 453 banking offices in California with aggregate resources of over US$1.4 billion.[[19]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America#cite_note-19) There is a replica of the 1909 Bank of Italy branch bank in [History Park](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_Park_at_Kelley_Park "History Park at Kelley Park") in San Jose, and the 1925 [Bank of Italy Building](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_Italy_Building_\(San_Jose,_California\) "Bank of Italy Building \(San Jose, California\)") is an important [downtown](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Downtown "Downtown") landmark. Giannini sought to build a national bank, expanding into most of the western states as well as into the [insurance industry](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Insurance_industry "Insurance industry"), under the aegis of his holding company, [Transamerica Corporation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Transamerica_Corporation "Transamerica Corporation"). 
In 1953 regulators succeeded in forcing the separation of [Transamerica Corporation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Transamerica_Corporation "Transamerica Corporation") and Bank of America under the [Clayton Antitrust Act](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Clayton_Antitrust_Act "Clayton Antitrust Act").[[20]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America#cite_note-20) The passage of the [Bank Holding Company Act of 1956](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_Holding_Company_Act_of_1956 "Bank Holding Company Act of 1956") prohibited banks from owning [non-banking subsidiaries](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Non-bank_subsidiary "Non-bank subsidiary") such as insurance companies. Bank of America and Transamerica were separated, with the latter company continuing in the insurance sector. However, federal banking regulators prohibited Bank of America's interstate banking activity, and Bank of America's domestic banks outside California were forced into a separate company that eventually became [First Interstate Bancorp](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/First_Interstate_Bancorp "First Interstate Bancorp"), later acquired by [Wells Fargo and Company](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wells_Fargo_and_Company "Wells Fargo and Company") in 1996. Only in the 1980s, with a change in federal banking legislation and regulation, could Bank of America again expand its domestic consumer banking activity outside California. 
New technologies also allowed the direct linking of [credit cards](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Credit_card "Credit card") with individual bank accounts. In 1958, the bank introduced the BankAmericard, which changed its name to [Visa](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Visa_Inc. "Visa Inc.") in 1977.[[21]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America#cite_note-21) A coalition of regional bankcard associations introduced Interbank in 1966 to compete with BankAmericard. Interbank became Master Charge in 1966 and then [Mastercard](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mastercard "Mastercard") in 1979.[[22]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America#cite_note-Stearns-22)
From February 1970 through September 1971, there were 66 attacks on Bank of America branches in California, including 53 bombings or fire-bombings, and 13 arson fires. There were "few injuries" and the property damage cost about $500,000, 80% of which was from the burning of the Isla Vista branch during a February 1970 riot.[[23]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America#cite_note-23)
### Expansion outside California
[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Bank_of_America&action=edit&section=4 "Edit section: Expansion outside California")]
[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3c/BankAmerica_logo.png/250px-BankAmerica_logo.png)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:BankAmerica_logo.png)Bank of America's logo from 1969 to 1998 [![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e7/Bank_of_America_Tower_in_Manhattan_2015.jpg/250px-Bank_of_America_Tower_in_Manhattan_2015.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Bank_of_America_Tower_in_Manhattan_2015.jpg)[Bank of America Tower](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America_Tower_\(Manhattan\) "Bank of America Tower \(Manhattan\)"), headquarters for Bank of America's [investment banking](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Investment_banking "Investment banking") operations, seen from [Bryant Park](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bryant_Park "Bryant Park") in [Midtown Manhattan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Midtown_Manhattan "Midtown Manhattan"), in 2015
Following passage of the [Bank Holding Company Act of 1956](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_Holding_Company_Act_of_1956 "Bank Holding Company Act of 1956") by the [U.S. Congress](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Congress "United States Congress"),[[24]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America#cite_note-24) BankAmerica Corporation was established for the purpose of owning and operating Bank of America and its subsidiaries. 
In 1983, Bank of America expanded outside [California](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/California "California"), through acquisition, orchestrated in part by [Stephen McLin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stephen_McLin "Stephen McLin") of [Seafirst Corporation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seafirst_Corporation "Seafirst Corporation") in [Seattle](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle "Seattle"), and its wholly owned banking subsidiary, Seattle-First National Bank.[[25]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America#cite_note-:1-25) Seafirst was at risk of seizure by the federal government after becoming insolvent due to a series of bad loans to the [oil industry](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Petroleum_industry "Petroleum industry"). BankAmerica continued to operate its new subsidiary as Seafirst rather than Bank of America until the 1998 merger with NationsBank.[[25]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America#cite_note-:1-25)
BankAmerica experienced huge losses in 1986 and 1987 due to the placement of a series of bad loans in the [Third World](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Third_World "Third World"). The company fired its CEO, [Sam Armacost](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Samuel_Armacost "Samuel Armacost"), in 1986. Though Armacost blamed the problems on his predecessor, [A. W. (Tom) Clausen](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alden_W._Clausen "Alden W. Clausen"), Clausen was appointed to replace Armacost.[_[citation needed](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] The losses resulted in a huge decline of BankAmerica stock, making it vulnerable to a hostile [takeover](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Takeover "Takeover"). [First Interstate Bancorp](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/First_Interstate_Bancorp "First Interstate Bancorp") of Los Angeles (which had originated from banks once owned by BankAmerica), launched such a bid in the fall of 1986, although BankAmerica rebuffed it, mostly by selling operations.[[26]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America#cite_note-26) It sold its FinanceAmerica subsidiary to [Chrysler](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chrysler "Chrysler") and the brokerage firm [Charles Schwab and Co.](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Charles_Schwab_Corporation "Charles Schwab Corporation") back to [Mr. Schwab](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Charles_R._Schwab "Charles R. Schwab"). It also sold [Bank of America and Italy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America_and_Italy "Bank of America and Italy") to [Deutsche Bank](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deutsche_Bank "Deutsche Bank"). By the time of the [1987 stock-market crash](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Black_Monday_\(1987\) "Black Monday \(1987\)"), BankAmerica's share price had fallen to $8, but by 1992 it had rebounded mightily to become one of the biggest gainers of that half-decade.[_[citation needed](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]
BankAmerica's next big acquisition came in 1992. The company acquired Security Pacific Corporation and its subsidiary [Security Pacific National Bank](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Security_Pacific_Bank "Security Pacific Bank") in California and other banks in [Arizona](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arizona "Arizona"), [Idaho](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Idaho "Idaho"), [Oregon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oregon "Oregon"), and [Washington](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Washington_\(state\) "Washington \(state\)"), which Security Pacific had acquired in a series of acquisitions in the late 1980s. This represented, at the time, the largest bank acquisition in history.[[27]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America#cite_note-27) Federal regulators, however, forced the sale of roughly half of Security Pacific's [Washington](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Washington,_D.C. "Washington, D.C.") subsidiary, the former [Rainier Bank](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rainier_Bank "Rainier Bank"), as the combination of Seafirst and Security Pacific Washington would have given BankAmerica too large a share of the market in that state. The Washington branches were divided and sold to West One Bancorp (now [U.S. Bancorp](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/U.S._Bancorp "U.S. Bancorp")) and [KeyBank](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/KeyBank "KeyBank").[[28]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America#cite_note-28) Later that year, BankAmerica expanded into Nevada by acquiring Valley Bank of Nevada.[[29]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America#cite_note-29)
In 1994, BankAmerica acquired the [Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Co.](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Continental_Illinois_National_Bank_and_Trust_Co. "Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Co.") of Chicago. At the time, no bank possessed the resources to bail out Continental, so the federal government operated the bank for nearly a decade.[[30]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America#cite_note-30) [Illinois](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Illinois "Illinois") then regulated branch banking extremely heavily, so Bank of America Illinois was a single-unit bank until the 21st century. BankAmerica moved its national lending department to Chicago in an effort to establish a financial beachhead in the region.[[31]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America#cite_note-31)
These mergers helped BankAmerica Corporation to once again become the largest U.S. bank holding company in terms of deposits, but the company fell to second place in 1997 behind North Carolina's fast-growing [NationsBank Corporation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NationsBank_Corporation "NationsBank Corporation"), and to third in 1998 behind [First Union](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/First_Union "First Union") Corp.[_[citation needed](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]
On the capital markets side, the acquisition of Continental Illinois helped BankAmerica to build a leveraged finance origination- and distribution business, which allowed the firm's existing broker-dealer, BancAmerica Securities (originally named BA Securities), to become a full-service franchise.[[32]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America#cite_note-32) In addition, in 1997, BankAmerica acquired [Robertson Stephens](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robertson_Stephens "Robertson Stephens"), a San Franciscobased investment bank specializing in high technology for $540 million.[[33]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America#cite_note-33) Robertson Stephens was integrated into BancAmerica Securities, and the combined subsidiary was renamed "BancAmerica Robertson Stephens".[[34]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America#cite_note-34)
### Merger of NationsBank and BankAmerica
[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Bank_of_America&action=edit&section=5 "Edit section: Merger of NationsBank and BankAmerica")]
[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4d/Bank_of_America_1998.svg/250px-Bank_of_America_1998.svg.png)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Bank_of_America_1998.svg)Bank of America's logo used from 1998 to 2018
In 1997, BankAmerica lent investment management firm [D. E. Shaw & Co.](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/D._E._Shaw_%26_Co. "D. E. Shaw & Co.") $1.4 billion to run various businesses for the bank.[[35]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America#cite_note-35) However, D.E. Shaw suffered significant loss during the [1998 Russian financial crisis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1998_Russian_financial_crisis "1998 Russian financial crisis").[[36]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America#cite_note-36)[[37]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America#cite_note-37) [NationsBank](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NationsBank "NationsBank") of Charlotte acquired BankAmerica in 1998 in what was the largest bank acquisition in history at that time.[[38]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America#cite_note-38)
While NationsBank was the nominal survivor, the merged bank took the better-known name of Bank of America. Hence, the holding company was renamed Bank of America Corporation, while NationsBank, N.A. merged with Bank of America NT&SA to form Bank of America, N.A. as the remaining legal bank entity.[[39]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America#cite_note-39) The combined bank operates under Federal Charter 13044, which was granted to Giannini's Bank of Italy on March 1, 1927. However, the merged company was and still is headquartered in Charlotte, and retains NationsBank's pre-1998 stock price history. All [U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/U.S._Securities_and_Exchange_Commission "U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission") (SEC) filings before 1998 are listed under NationsBank, not Bank of America. NationsBank president, chairman, and CEO [Hugh McColl](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hugh_McColl "Hugh McColl"), took on the same roles with the merged company.[_[citation needed](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]
In 1998, Bank of America possessed combined assets of $570 billion, as well as 4,800 branches in 22 U.S. states.[_[citation needed](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] Despite the size of the two companies, federal regulators insisted only upon the divestiture of 13 branches in [New Mexico](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_Mexico "New Mexico"), in towns that would be left with only a single bank following the combination.[[40]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America#cite_note-40) These branches were sold to [BOK Financial Corporation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/BOK_Financial_Corporation "BOK Financial Corporation"), which operates them under the name "Bank of Albuquerque".[[41]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America#cite_note-41)[[42]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America#cite_note-42) The broker-dealer, NationsBanc Montgomery Securities, was named [Banc of America Securities](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Banc_of_America_Securities "Banc of America Securities") in 1998.[_[citation needed](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]
### Banc of America Securities
[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Bank_of_America&action=edit&section=6 "Edit section: Banc of America Securities")]
Banc of America Securities[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/21/Banc_of_America_Securities_Logo_03.2002.svg/250px-Banc_of_America_Securities_Logo_03.2002.svg.png)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Banc_of_America_Securities_Logo_03.2002.svg)
