## Charitable efforts
[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Bank_of_America&action=edit&section=33 "Edit section: Charitable efforts")]
[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e5/Bank_of_America_LA_Pride_2011.jpg/250px-Bank_of_America_LA_Pride_2011.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Bank_of_America_LA_Pride_2011.jpg)Bank of America volunteers at an _[LGBT](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/LGBT "LGBT")_ pride parade in Los Angeles in 2011
In 1998, the bank made a ten-year commitment of $350 billion to provide affordable mortgages, build affordable housing, support small businesses and create jobs in disadvantaged neighbourhoods.[[128]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America#cite_note-128) In 2004, the bank pledged $750 million over a ten-year period for community development lending and affordable housing programs.[[129]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America#cite_note-129)
In 2007, the bank offered employees a $3,000 rebate for the purchase of [hybrid vehicles](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybrid_vehicle "Hybrid vehicle"). The company also provided a $1,000 rebate or a lower interest rate for customers whose homes qualified as energy efficient.[[130]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America#cite_note-130) In 2007, Bank of America partnered with Brighter Planet to offer an eco-friendly credit card, and later a debit card, which help build renewable energy projects with each purchase.[[131]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America#cite_note-131) Bank of America has also donated money to help health centers in Massachusetts[[132]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America#cite_note-132) and made a $1 million donation in 2007 to help homeless shelters in [Miami](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Miami "Miami").[[133]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America#cite_note-133)
In [India](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India "India"), Bank of America donates to the preservation and documentation of relics. Since 2010, under the stewardship of Kaku Nakhate, president and head of BoA India, the company has supported arts and culture in the country, including sponsoring the Children's Museum at CSMVS (Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj Vastu Sangrahalaya, formerly known as Prince of Wales Museum).[[134]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America#cite_note-134)
## Lawsuits, controversies, and incidents
[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Bank_of_America&action=edit&section=34 "Edit section: Lawsuits, controversies, and incidents")]
### Lawsuits
[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Bank_of_America&action=edit&section=35 "Edit section: Lawsuits")]
#### Parmalat lawsuit
[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Bank_of_America&action=edit&section=36 "Edit section: Parmalat lawsuit")]
[Parmalat](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Parmalat "Parmalat") SpA is a multinational Italian dairy and food corporation. Following [Parmalat's 2003 bankruptcy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Parmalat_bankruptcy_timeline "Parmalat bankruptcy timeline"), the company sued Bank of America for $10 billion, alleging the bank profited from its knowledge of Parmalat's financial difficulties. The parties announced a settlement in July 2009, resulting in Bank of America paying Parmalat $98.5 million in October 2009.[[135]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America#cite_note-135)[[136]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America#cite_note-136) In a related case, on April 18, 2011, an Italian court acquitted Bank of America and three other large banks, along with their employees, of charges they assisted Parmalat in concealing its fraud, and of lacking sufficient internal controls to prevent such frauds. Prosecutors did not immediately say whether they would appeal the rulings. In [Parma](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Parma "Parma"), the banks were still charged with covering up the fraud.[[137]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America#cite_note-137)
#### Mortgage abuses
[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Bank_of_America&action=edit&section=37 "Edit section: Mortgage abuses")]
In August 2011, Bank of America was sued for $10 billion by [American International Group](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_International_Group "American International Group") over an alleged "massive fraud" on mortgage debt.[[138]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America#cite_note-138) Another lawsuit filed against Bank of America, pertained to $57.5 billion in [mortgage-backed securities](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mortgage-backed_securities "Mortgage-backed securities") Bank of America sold to [Fannie Mae](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fannie_Mae "Fannie Mae") and [Freddie Mac](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Freddie_Mac "Freddie Mac").[[139]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America#cite_note-139) That December, Bank of America agreed to pay $335 million to settle a federal government claim that Countrywide Financial had [discriminated](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mortgage_discrimination "Mortgage discrimination") against Hispanic and [African-American](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/African-American "African-American") homebuyers from 2004 to 2008, prior to being acquired by BofA.[[140]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America#cite_note-140) In September 2012, BofA settled out of court for $2.4 billion in a class action lawsuit filed by BofA shareholders who felt they were misled about the purchase of [Merrill Lynch](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Merrill_Lynch "Merrill Lynch").[[141]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America#cite_note-141)
On February 9, 2012, it was announced that the five largest mortgage servicers (Ally/GMAC, Bank of America, Citi, JPMorgan Chase, and Wells Fargo) agreed to a historic settlement with the federal government and 49 states.[[142]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America#cite_note-142) The settlement, known as the National Mortgage Settlement (NMS), required the servicers to provide about $26 billion in relief to distressed homeowners and indirect payments to the states and the federal government. This settlement amount makes the NMS the second largest civil settlement in U.S. history, only trailing the [Tobacco Master Settlement Agreement](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tobacco_Master_Settlement_Agreement "Tobacco Master Settlement Agreement").[[143]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America#cite_note-143) The five banks were also required to comply with 305 new mortgage servicing standards. Oklahoma held out and agreed to settle with the banks separately. 
On October 24, 2012, American [federal prosecutors](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Federal_prosecutor "Federal prosecutor") filed a $1 billion [civil lawsuit](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Civil_lawsuit "Civil lawsuit") against Bank of America for [mortgage fraud](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mortgage_fraud "Mortgage fraud") under the [False Claims Act](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/False_Claims_Act "False Claims Act"), which provides for possible penalties of triple the damages suffered. The government asserted that [Countrywide](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Countrywide_Financial "Countrywide Financial"), which was acquired by Bank of America, [rubber-stamped](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rubber_stamp_\(politics\) "Rubber stamp \(politics\)") mortgage loans to risky borrowers and forced taxpayers to guarantee billions of bad loans through [Fannie Mae](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fannie_Mae "Fannie Mae") and [Freddie Mac](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Freddie_Mac "Freddie Mac"). The suit was filed by [Preet Bharara](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Preet_Bharara "Preet Bharara"), the United States attorney in [Manhattan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Manhattan "Manhattan"), the inspector general of [FHFA](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/FHFA "FHFA") and the special inspector for the [Troubled Asset Relief Program](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Troubled_Asset_Relief_Program "Troubled Asset Relief Program").[[144]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America#cite_note-144) In March 2014, Bank of America settled the suit by agreeing to pay $6.3 billion to Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac and to buy back around $3.2 billion worth of mortgage bonds.[[145]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America#cite_note-145)
A$7.5 million settlement was reached in April 2014 with former chief financial officer for Bank of America, Joe L. Price, over allegations that the bank's management withheld material information related to its 2008 merger with [Merrill Lynch](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Merrill_Lynch "Merrill Lynch").[[146]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America#cite_note-146) In August 2014, the [United States Department of Justice](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Department_of_Justice "United States Department of Justice") and the bank agreed to a $16.65 billion agreement over the sale of risky, mortgage-backed securities before the [Great Recession](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Great_Recession "Great Recession"); the loans behind the securities were transferred to the company when it acquired banks such as Merrill Lynch and Countrywide in 2008.[[147]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America#cite_note-LA_Times_2014-147) As a whole, the three firms provided $965 billion of mortgage-backed securities from 2004 to 2008.[[148]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America#cite_note-148) The settlement was structured to give $7 billion in consumer relief and $9.65 billion in penalty payments to the federal government and state governments; [California](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/California "California"), for instance, received $300 million to recompense public pension funds.[[147]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America#cite_note-LA_Times_2014-147)[[149]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America#cite_note-149) The settlement was the largest in United States history between a single company and the federal government.[[150]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America#cite_note-150)[[151]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America#cite_note-151)
#### Settlement with homeowners
[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Bank_of_America&action=edit&section=38 "Edit section: Settlement with homeowners")]
On March 14, 2011, members of hacker group [Anonymous](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anonymous_\(group\) "Anonymous \(group\)") began releasing emails said to be from a former Bank of America employee. According to the group, the emails documented alleged "corruption and fraud". The source, identified publicly as Brian Penny,[[152]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America#cite_note-152) was a former LPI Specialist from Balboa Insurance, a firm which used to be owned by the bank, but was sold to Australian Reinsurance Company QBE.[[153]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America#cite_note-153) On April 7, 2014, Bank of America and QBE settled a class-action lawsuit stemming from the leak for $228 million.[[154]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America#cite_note-154)
#### Unfair billing practices
[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Bank_of_America&action=edit&section=39 "Edit section: Unfair billing practices")]
In April 2014, the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau (CFPB) ordered Bank of America to provide an estimated $727 million in relief to consumers harmed by practices related to credit card add-on products. According to the Bureau, roughly 1.4 million customers were affected by deceptive marketing of add-on products, and 1.9 million customers were illegally charged for credit monitoring and reporting services they were not receiving. The deceptive marketing misconduct involved telemarketing scripts containing misstatements and off-script sales pitches made by telemarketers that were misleading and omitted pertinent information. The unfair billing practices involved billing customers for privacy-related products without having the authorization necessary to perform the credit monitoring and credit report retrieval services. As a result, the company billed customers for services they did not receive, unfairly charged consumers for interest and fees, illegally charged approximately 1.9 million accounts, and failed to provide the product benefit.[[155]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America#cite_note-155) In May 2022, CFPB ordered Bank of America to pay $10 million in penalties for illegal garnishments.[[156]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America#cite_note-156)
#### Discrimination
[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Bank_of_America&action=edit&section=40 "Edit section: Discrimination")]
In 2018, former senior executive [Omeed Malik](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Omeed_Malik "Omeed Malik") filed a $100 million [arbitration](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arbitration "Arbitration") case through [FINRA](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Financial_Industry_Regulatory_Authority "Financial Industry Regulatory Authority") against Bank of America after the company investigated him for alleged [sexual misconduct](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sexual_misconduct "Sexual misconduct").[[157]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America#cite_note-157) His [defamation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Defamation "Defamation") claim was on the basis of [retaliation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Workplace_retaliation "Workplace retaliation"), [breach of contract](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Breach_of_contract "Breach of contract"), and [discrimination](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Discrimination "Discrimination") against his [Muslim](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Muslim "Muslim") background.[[158]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America#cite_note-158) Malik received an eight-figure [settlement](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Settlement_\(litigation\) "Settlement \(litigation\)") in July of the same year.[[159]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America#cite_note-159)[[160]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America#cite_note-160)
#### South African currency manipulation
[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Bank_of_America&action=edit&section=41 "Edit section: South African currency manipulation")]
In April 2015, the [Competition Commission](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Competition_Commission_\(South_Africa\) "Competition Commission \(South Africa\)") lodged an investigation into cartel conduct by major banks in the foreign currency exchange market affecting the [South African rand](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/South_African_rand "South African rand"). The investigation included Bank of America along with other banks including Barclays Bank Plc, CitiGroup Inc, JP Morgan Chase & Co, Standard New York Securities Inc and others. The above traders in foreign currencies are under investigation for directly or indirectly fixing prices on bids, offers and bid-offer spreads with regard to spot, futures and forwards currency trades. The conduct under investigation has the effect of distorting foreign exchange prices and artificially inflating the cost of trading in foreign currency, in relation to the rand.[[161]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America#cite_note-161)
#### Fake accounts, junk fees and withheld rewards
[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Bank_of_America&action=edit&section=42 "Edit section: Fake accounts, junk fees and withheld rewards")]
In 2023, the [Consumer Financial Protection Bureau](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Consumer_Financial_Protection_Bureau "Consumer Financial Protection Bureau") said that a total of $250 million in fines and compensation has been levied against Bank of America for "deceptive practices that harmed hundreds of thousands of consumers", including double charging insufficient funds fees, withholding credit card rewards, and opening accounts without the knowledge or permission of customers.[[162]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America#cite_note-162)
### Controversies
[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Bank_of_America&action=edit&section=43 "Edit section: Controversies")]
#### Consumer credit controversies
[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Bank_of_America&action=edit&section=44 "Edit section: Consumer credit controversies")]
In January 2008, Bank of America began notifying some customers without payment problems that their interest rates were more than doubled, up to 28%. The bank was criticized for raising rates on customers in good standing, and for declining to explain why it had done so.[[163]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America#cite_note-163)[[164]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America#cite_note-164) In September 2009, a Bank of America credit card customer, Ann Minch, posted a video on YouTube criticizing the bank for raising her interest rate. After the video went [viral](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Viral_video "Viral video"), she was contacted by a Bank of America representative who lowered her rate. The story attracted national attention from television and internet commentators.[[165]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America#cite_note-165)[[166]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America#cite_note-166)[[167]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America#cite_note-167) In 2010, the bank was criticized for allegedly seizing three properties that were not under their ownership, apparently due to incorrect addresses on their legal documents.[[168]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America#cite_note-wronghomes-168)
#### State of Arizona investigation
[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Bank_of_America&action=edit&section=45 "Edit section: State of Arizona investigation")]
In 2010 the state of [Arizona](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arizona "Arizona") launched an investigation into Bank of America for misleading homeowners who sought to modify their [mortgage loans](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mortgage_loan "Mortgage loan"). According to the attorney general of Arizona, the bank "repeatedly has deceived" such mortgagors. In response to the investigation, the bank has given some modifications on the condition that the homeowners remove some information criticizing the bank online.[[169]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America#cite_note-169)
#### Investment in coal mining
[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Bank_of_America&action=edit&section=46 "Edit section: Investment in coal mining")]
On May 6, 2015, Bank of America announced it would reduce its financial exposure to coal companies. The announcement came following pressure from universities and environmental groups. The new policy was announced as part of the bank's decision to continue to reduce credit exposure over time to the coal mining sector.[[170]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America#cite_note-Business_Insider-170)
### Incidents
[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Bank_of_America&action=edit&section=47 "Edit section: Incidents")]
#### Wikileaks incident
[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Bank_of_America&action=edit&section=48 "Edit section: Wikileaks incident")]
In October 2009, [Julian Assange](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Julian_Assange "Julian Assange") of [WikiLeaks](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/WikiLeaks "WikiLeaks") claimed that his organization possessed a 5 gigabyte [hard drive](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hard_drive "Hard drive") formerly used by a Bank of America executive and that Wikileaks intended to publish its contents.[[171]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America#cite_note-171) In November 2010, _[Forbes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Forbes "Forbes")_ published an interview with Assange in which he stated his intent to publish information which would turn a major U.S. bank "inside out".[[172]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America#cite_note-172) In response to this announcement, Bank of America stock dropped 3.2%.[[173]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America#cite_note-173)
In December 2010, Bank of America announced that it would no longer service requests to transfer funds to WikiLeaks,[[174]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America#cite_note-CB1-174) stating that "Bank of America joins in the actions previously announced by [MasterCard](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MasterCard "MasterCard"), [PayPal](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PayPal "PayPal"), [Visa](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Visa_Inc. "Visa Inc.") Europe, and others and will not process transactions of any type that we have reason to believe are intended for WikiLeaks... This decision is based upon our reasonable belief that WikiLeaks may be engaged in activities that are, among other things, inconsistent with our internal policies for processing payments."[[175]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America#cite_note-175)
Later in December, it was announced that Bank of America purchased more than 300 [Internet domain names](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Internet_domain_name "Internet domain name") in an attempt to preempt bad publicity that might be forthcoming in the anticipated WikiLeaks release. The domain names included as _BrianMoynihanBlows.com_ , _BrianMoynihanSucks.com_ and similar names for other top executives of the bank.[[176]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America#cite_note-176)[[177]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America#cite_note-177)[[178]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America#cite_note-178)[[179]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America#cite_note-179)
Sometime before August 2011, WikiLeaks claimed that 5 GB of Bank of America leaks was part of the deletion of over 3500 communications by [Daniel Domscheit-Berg](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Daniel_Domscheit-Berg "Daniel Domscheit-Berg"), a now ex-WikiLeaks volunteer.[[180]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America#cite_note-twitter-180)[[181]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America#cite_note-twitterboa-181)
#### Ryan Coogler incident
[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Bank_of_America&action=edit&section=49 "Edit section: Ryan Coogler incident")]
In March 2022, the bank was involved in an incident related to filmmaker [Ryan Coogler](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ryan_Coogler "Ryan Coogler"), who was wrongly targeted as a bank robber and detained by the police in [Atlanta](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Atlanta "Atlanta"), after Coogler tried to withdraw cash in the local branch of the Bank of America. After his identity was verified with both his California state ID card and his Bank of America card, Coogler was released and the bank released an apology statement. According to a number of sources, the bank's teller hadn't checked Coogler's ID to verify if he was the owner of the bank account before she asked the bank's supervisor to call police.[[182]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America#cite_note-182)[[183]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America#cite_note-183)[[184]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America#cite_note-184)[[185]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America#cite_note-185)
#### Employee Fatalities
[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Bank_of_America&action=edit&section=50 "Edit section: Employee Fatalities")]
In 2013, an intern in the London office was found dead.[[186]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America#cite_note-186) It was reported that the intern had worked until 6am for the preceding three days before his death, and that this was typical of expectations at the bank.[[187]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America#cite_note-187) The incident sparked much debate regarding working hours at the firm, which resulted in rival firm Goldman Sachs capping intern hours to 17 per day.[[188]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America#cite_note-188)
In 2024, Leo Lukensas III a, former [US Army Special Forces Veteran](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Army_Special_Forces "United States Army Special Forces") working in the investment banking division also died following heart problems.[[189]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America#cite_note-189) It was reported that the investment bank has a culture of working weeks in excess of 100 hours per week, and managers encouraging employees to under report their working hours to HR.[[190]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America#cite_note-190) Lukensas was reported to be seeking to leave the firm, citing excessive working hours.[[191]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America#cite_note-191) His manager, Gary Howe, was removed as a leader, although not fired from his post following the incident.[_[citation needed](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]
#### Debanking
[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Bank_of_America&action=edit&section=51 "Edit section: Debanking")]
Bank of America has been accused of terminating the accounts of people based on their religious or political views, often with alleged victims being aligned with conservative causes. in 2023, a Christian charity primarily focused on charitable work in Africa reportedly had its account suddenly terminated without explanation. The bank refused to explain anything until contacted by members of the media, where after refusing to explain anything to the customer, it proceeded to make a series of allegedly false accusations against the customer to a reporter. In response, a shareholder action proposal was made at a Bank of America annual meeting.[[192]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America#cite_note-192) in 2025, United States, president Donald Trump accused Bank of America CEO Brian, Moynahan of political debanking, stating he hoped the CEO would open his bank to conservatives.[[193]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America#cite_note-193)
#### Customer Privacy
[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Bank_of_America&action=edit&section=52 "Edit section: Customer Privacy")]
The bank faced heavy criticism and a congressional investigation following the events of January 6, 2021. The bank was accused of without compulsion handing over extensive private profile information of any individual who may have shopped at Cabelas, rented a hotel anywhere in Virginia, went to an ATM in DC, on January 5-7, 2021, even though it had been under no compulsion to do so. The bank claimed in its defense only that it was allowed to do so.[[194]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America#cite_note-194)
## Competition
[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Bank_of_America&action=edit&section=53 "Edit section: Competition")]
Bank of America's major competitors are [Wells Fargo](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wells_Fargo "Wells Fargo"), [Santander](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Santander_Group "Santander Group"), [PNC Financial Services](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PNC_Financial_Services "PNC Financial Services"), [Ally Financial](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ally_Financial "Ally Financial"), [Capital One](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Capital_One "Capital One"), [JPMorgan Chase Bank](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chase_Bank "Chase Bank"), [US Bank](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/US_Bank "US Bank"), [Citizens Financial Group](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizens_Financial_Group "Citizens Financial Group"), [Citigroup](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citigroup "Citigroup"), [M&T Bank](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/M%26T_Bank "M&T Bank"), and [Truist](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Truist_Financial "Truist Financial"). 
## Notable buildings
[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Bank_of_America&action=edit&section=54 "Edit section: Notable buildings")]
[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ce/Bank_of_America_Atlanta_1.jpg/250px-Bank_of_America_Atlanta_1.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Bank_of_America_Atlanta_1.jpg)[Bank of America Plaza](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America_Plaza_\(Atlanta\) "Bank of America Plaza \(Atlanta\)") in [Atlanta](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Atlanta "Atlanta"), the tallest building in the [Southern United States](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Southern_United_States "Southern United States") [![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/aa/Bank_of_America_Stadium.jpg/250px-Bank_of_America_Stadium.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Bank_of_America_Stadium.jpg)[Bank of America Stadium](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America_Stadium "Bank of America Stadium"), home to the [Carolina Panthers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carolina_Panthers "Carolina Panthers") of the [National Football League](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Football_League "National Football League")
Notable buildings which Bank of America currently occupies include: 
  * [Bank of America Tower](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America_Tower_\(Phoenix\) "Bank of America Tower \(Phoenix\)") in [Phoenix, Arizona](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phoenix,_Arizona "Phoenix, Arizona")
  * [9454 Wilshire Boulevard](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/9454_Wilshire_Boulevard "9454 Wilshire Boulevard") in [Beverly Hills, California](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Beverly_Hills,_California "Beverly Hills, California")
  * [Bank of America Center](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America_Center_\(Los_Angeles\) "Bank of America Center \(Los Angeles\)") in [Los Angeles](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Los_Angeles "Los Angeles")

  * [City Place I](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/City_Place_I "City Place I"), also known as United Healthcare Center, in [Hartford, Connecticut](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hartford,_Connecticut "Hartford, Connecticut") (the tallest building in Connecticut)

In 2010, the bank completed construction of 1 Bank of America Center in [Charlotte center city](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Charlotte_center_city "Charlotte center city"). The tower, and accompanying hotel, is a [LEED-certified](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Leadership_in_Energy_and_Environmental_Design "Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design") building.[[195]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America#cite_note-195)
### Former buildings
[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Bank_of_America&action=edit&section=55 "Edit section: Former buildings")]
[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b8/Bank_of_America%2C_Loop_410%2C_San_Antonio%2C_TX_IMG_7852.JPG/250px-Bank_of_America%2C_Loop_410%2C_San_Antonio%2C_TX_IMG_7852.JPG)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Bank_of_America,_Loop_410,_San_Antonio,_TX_IMG_7852.JPG)A pyramid-shaped former Bank of America branch building towers over [Interstate 410](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Interstate_410 "Interstate 410") in [San Antonio, Texas](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/San_Antonio,_Texas "San Antonio, Texas"), in 2013
The [Robert B. Atwood Building](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robert_B._Atwood_Building "Robert B. Atwood Building") in [Anchorage, Alaska](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anchorage,_Alaska "Anchorage, Alaska"), was at one time named the Bank of America Center, renamed in conjunction with the bank's acquisition of building tenant Security Pacific Bank. This particular branch was later acquired by Alaska-based Northrim Bank and moved across the street to the [Linny Pacillo Parking Garage](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linny_Pacillo_Parking_Garage "Linny Pacillo Parking Garage"). 
The [Bank of America Building (Providence)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America_Building_\(Providence\) "Bank of America Building \(Providence\)") opened in 1928 as the Industrial Trust Building and remains the tallest building in Rhode Island. Through a number of mergers, it was later known as the Industrial National Bank building and the Fleet Bank building. The building was leased by Bank of America from 2004 to 2012 and has been vacant since March 2013. The building is commonly known as the Superman Building based on a popular belief that it was the model for the [Daily Planet](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Daily_Planet "Daily Planet") building in the [Superman](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Superman "Superman") comic books. 
[Miami Tower](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Miami_Tower "Miami Tower") in [Downtown Miami](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Greater_Downtown_Miami "Greater Downtown Miami"), known as Bank of America Tower for many years, was an iconic appearance in the television series _[Miami Vice](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Miami_Vice "Miami Vice")_.On April 18, 2012, the AIA's Florida Chapter placed the building on its list of Florida Architecture: 100 Years. 100 Places as the Bank of America Tower.[[196]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America#cite_note-196)
[TC Energy Center](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/TC_Energy_Center "TC Energy Center") in Houston, Texas, was previously known as Bank of America Center until Bank of America ended its tenancy in the building in June 2019. Designed in the [postmodern architecture](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Postmodern_architecture "Postmodern architecture") style by renowned architect [Philip Johnson](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Philip_Johnson "Philip Johnson"), the building has been one of the most recognizable landmarks of the downtown Houston skyline since it was completed in 1983.[[197]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America#cite_note-197)

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia
American multinational banking and financial services corporation
This article is about a commercial bank unaffiliated with any government. For the central bank of the United States, see [Federal Reserve](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Federal_Reserve "Federal Reserve").
See also: [Bank of America (19041998)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America_\(1904%E2%80%931998\) "Bank of America \(19041998\)")

The **Bank of America Corporation** (**Bank of America**) (often abbreviated **BofA** or **BoA**) is an American multinational [investment bank](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Investment_banking "Investment banking") and [financial services](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Financial_services "Financial services") [holding company](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Holding_company "Holding company") headquartered at the [Bank of America Corporate Center](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America_Corporate_Center "Bank of America Corporate Center") in [Charlotte, North Carolina](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Charlotte,_North_Carolina "Charlotte, North Carolina"), with [investment banking](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Investment_bank "Investment bank") and auxiliary headquarters in [Manhattan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Manhattan "Manhattan"). The bank was founded by the merger of [NationsBank](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NationsBank "NationsBank") and [Bank of America](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America_\(1904%E2%80%931998\) "Bank of America \(19041998\)") in 1998. It is the [second-largest banking institution](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_largest_banks_in_the_United_States "List of largest banks in the United States") in the United States and the second-largest bank in the world by [market capitalization](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Market_capitalization "Market capitalization"), both after [JPMorgan Chase](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/JPMorgan_Chase "JPMorgan Chase"). Bank of America is one of the [Big Four](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Big_Four_\(banking\)#United_States "Big Four \(banking\)") banking institutions of the United States.[[3]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America#cite_note-3) and one of eight [systemically important financial institutions](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Systemically_important_financial_institution "Systemically important financial institution") in the US. It serves about 10 percent of all American bank deposits, in direct competition with JPMorgan Chase, [Citigroup](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citigroup "Citigroup"), and [Wells Fargo](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wells_Fargo "Wells Fargo"). Its primary financial services revolve around [commercial banking](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Commercial_bank "Commercial bank"), [wealth management](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wealth_management "Wealth management"), and investment banking. Through mergers, the oldest branch of the Bank of America franchise can be traced to 1784, when [Massachusetts Bank](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/BankBoston#The_Massachusetts_Bank "BankBoston") was chartered, the first federally chartered joint-stock owned bank in the United States. Another branch of its history goes back to the U.S.-based [Bank of Italy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_Italy_\(United_States\) "Bank of Italy \(United States\)"), founded by [Amadeo Pietro Giannini](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amadeo_Giannini "Amadeo Giannini") in 1904, which provided various banking options to [Italian immigrants](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Italian_diaspora "Italian diaspora") who [faced service discrimination](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anti-Italianism "Anti-Italianism").[[4]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America#cite_note-PBSGiannini-4) Headquartered in [San Francisco, California](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/San_Francisco "San Francisco"), Giannini acquired [Banca d'America e d'Italia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Banca_d%27America_e_d%27Italia "Banca d'America e d'Italia"), in 1922 and eventually did business as Bank of America. 
In the 1950s, passage of landmark federal banking legislation facilitated rapid growth, quickly establishing prominent shares for the present bank's predecessors. After suffering significant losses during the [1998 Russian financial crisis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1998_Russian_financial_crisis "1998 Russian financial crisis"), BankAmerica, as it was then known, was acquired by the Charlotte-based [NationsBank](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NationsBank "NationsBank") for $62 billion. Following what was then the [largest bank acquisition in history](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_largest_mergers_and_acquisitions "List of largest mergers and acquisitions"), the Bank of America Corporation was founded. Through a series of mergers and acquisitions, it built upon its commercial banking business by establishing [Merrill Lynch](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Merrill_Lynch "Merrill Lynch") for wealth management and [Bank of America Merrill Lynch](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America_Merrill_Lynch "Bank of America Merrill Lynch") for investment banking in 2008 and 2009, respectively, and since renamed BofA Securities.[[5]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America#cite_note-ATLoffer-5)
Both Bank of America and Merrill Lynch Wealth Management retain large market shares in their respective offerings. The [investment bank](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Investment_banking "Investment banking") is considered within the "[Bulge Bracket](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bulge_Bracket "Bulge Bracket")" as the [third largest investment bank in the world](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_investment_banks "List of investment banks"), as of 2018[[update]](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Bank_of_America&action=edit).[[6]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America#cite_note-6) Its wealth management unit manages $1.08 trillion in [assets under management](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Assets_under_management "Assets under management") (AUM) as the [second largest wealth manager in the world](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Private_banking#Private_banking_rankings "Private banking"), after [UBS](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/UBS "UBS").[[7]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America#cite_note-7) In commercial banking, Bank of America has operations, but does not necessarily maintain retail branches in all 50 states of the United States, [Washington, D.C.](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Washington,_D.C. "Washington, D.C."), and over 40 other countries.[[8]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America#cite_note-8) Its commercial banking footprint encapsulates 46 million consumer and small business relationships at 4,600 banking centers and 16,000 [automated teller machines](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Automated_teller_machine "Automated teller machine") (ATMs). 
The bank's large market share, business activities, and economic impact has led to numerous lawsuits and investigations regarding both mortgages and financial disclosures dating back to the [2008 financial crisis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2008_financial_crisis "2008 financial crisis"). Its corporate practices of servicing the [middle class](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Middle_class "Middle class") and wider banking community have yielded a substantial market share since the early 20th century. As of August 2018[[update]](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Bank_of_America&action=edit), Bank of America has a $313.5 billion [market capitalization](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Market_capitalization "Market capitalization"), making it the [13th largest company in the world](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_public_corporations_by_market_capitalization "List of public corporations by market capitalization"). As the sixth largest American public company, it garnered $102.98 billion in sales as of June 2018[[update]](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Bank_of_America&action=edit).[[9]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America#cite_note-9) Bank of America was ranked No. 25 on the 2020 [Fortune 500](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fortune_500 "Fortune 500") rankings of the largest US corporations by total revenue.[[10]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America#cite_note-10) Likewise, Bank of America was also ranked No. 6 on the 2023 Global 2000 rankings done by Forbes.[[11]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America#cite_note-11) Bank of America was named the "World's Best Bank" by the _[Euromoney Institutional Investor](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Euromoney_Institutional_Investor "Euromoney Institutional Investor")_ in its 2018 Awards for Excellence.[[12]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America#cite_note-12)[[13]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America#cite_note-13)
## History
[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Bank_of_America&action=edit&section=1 "Edit section: History")]
[Bank of America, Los Angeles](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America,_Los_Angeles "Bank of America, Los Angeles") was founded in California in 1923. In 1928, this entity was acquired by [Bank of Italy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_Italy_\(United_States\) "Bank of Italy \(United States\)") of San Francisco, which took the Bank of America name two years later.[[14]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America#cite_note-britannica.com-14)
The eastern portion of the Bank of America franchise can be traced to 1784, when [Massachusetts Bank](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/BankBoston#The_Massachusetts_Bank "BankBoston") was chartered, the first federally chartered joint-stock owned bank in the United States and only the second bank to receive a charter in the United States. This bank became [FleetBoston](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/FleetBoston_Financial "FleetBoston Financial"), with which Bank of America merged in 2004. In 1874, [Commercial National Bank](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Commercial_National_Bank "Commercial National Bank") was founded in Charlotte. That bank merged with American Trust Company in 1958 to form American Commercial Bank.[[15]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America#cite_note-15) Two years later it became [North Carolina National Bank](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/North_Carolina_National_Bank "North Carolina National Bank") when it merged with Security National Bank of Greensboro. In 1991, it merged with [C&S](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizens_%26_Southern_National_Bank "Citizens & Southern National Bank")/[Sovran](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sovran_Bank "Sovran Bank") Corporation of [Atlanta](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Atlanta "Atlanta") and [Norfolk](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Norfolk,_Virginia "Norfolk, Virginia") to form [NationsBank](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NationsBank "NationsBank"). 
The central portion of the franchise dates to 1910, when Commercial National Bank and Continental National Bank of Chicago merged in 1910 to form Continental & Commercial National Bank, which evolved into [Continental Illinois National Bank & Trust](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Continental_Illinois "Continental Illinois"). 
### Bank of America
[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Bank_of_America&action=edit&section=2 "Edit section: Bank of America")]
Main article: [Bank of Italy (United States)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_Italy_\(United_States\) "Bank of Italy \(United States\)")
[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ea/M._A._P._Giannini%2C_pr%C3%A9sident_de_la_Banque_d%27Italie.jpg/250px-M._A._P._Giannini%2C_pr%C3%A9sident_de_la_Banque_d%27Italie.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:M._A._P._Giannini,_pr%C3%A9sident_de_la_Banque_d%27Italie.jpg)[Amadeo Giannini](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amadeo_Giannini "Amadeo Giannini"), founder of [Bank of Italy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_Italy_\(United_States\) "Bank of Italy \(United States\)"), in 1927
The history of Bank of America dates back to October 17, 1904, when [Amadeo Pietro Giannini](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amadeo_Giannini "Amadeo Giannini") (18701949) founded the [Bank of Italy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_Italy_\(United_States\) "Bank of Italy \(United States\)"), in San Francisco.[[14]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America#cite_note-britannica.com-14) In 1922, Bank of America, Los Angeles was established with Giannini as a minority investor. The two banks merged in 1928 and consolidated with other bank holdings to create what would become the largest banking institution in the country.[[16]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America#cite_note-:0-16)
In 1918, another corporation, Bancitaly Corporation, was organized by A. P. Giannini, the largest stockholder of which was Stockholders Auxiliary Corporation.[_[citation needed](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] This company acquired the stocks of various banks located in New York City and certain foreign countries.[_[citation needed](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]
In 1928, Giannini merged his bank with [Bank of America, Los Angeles](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America,_Los_Angeles "Bank of America, Los Angeles"), headed by [Orra E. Monnette](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Orra_E._Monnette "Orra E. Monnette"). Bank of Italy was renamed on November 3, 1930, to [Bank of America National Trust and Savings Association](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America_NT%26SA "Bank of America NT&SA"),[[17]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America#cite_note-17) which was the only such designated bank in the United States at that time. Giannini and Monnette headed the resulting company, serving as co-chairs.[[18]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America#cite_note-18)
### Expansion in California
[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Bank_of_America&action=edit&section=3 "Edit section: Expansion in California")]
[![Early Bank of America building](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/The_Bank_of_America_8d28756v.jpg/250px-The_Bank_of_America_8d28756v.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:The_Bank_of_America_8d28756v.jpg)Entrance to Bank of America in [San Francisco](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/San_Francisco "San Francisco") in 1943
Giannini introduced branch banking shortly after 1909 legislation in California allowed for branch banking in the state, establishing the bank's first branch outside San Francisco in 1909 in San Jose. By 1929 the bank had 453 banking offices in California with aggregate resources of over US$1.4 billion.[[19]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America#cite_note-19) There is a replica of the 1909 Bank of Italy branch bank in [History Park](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_Park_at_Kelley_Park "History Park at Kelley Park") in San Jose, and the 1925 [Bank of Italy Building](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_Italy_Building_\(San_Jose,_California\) "Bank of Italy Building \(San Jose, California\)") is an important [downtown](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Downtown "Downtown") landmark. Giannini sought to build a national bank, expanding into most of the western states as well as into the [insurance industry](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Insurance_industry "Insurance industry"), under the aegis of his holding company, [Transamerica Corporation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Transamerica_Corporation "Transamerica Corporation"). 
In 1953 regulators succeeded in forcing the separation of [Transamerica Corporation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Transamerica_Corporation "Transamerica Corporation") and Bank of America under the [Clayton Antitrust Act](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Clayton_Antitrust_Act "Clayton Antitrust Act").[[20]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America#cite_note-20) The passage of the [Bank Holding Company Act of 1956](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_Holding_Company_Act_of_1956 "Bank Holding Company Act of 1956") prohibited banks from owning [non-banking subsidiaries](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Non-bank_subsidiary "Non-bank subsidiary") such as insurance companies. Bank of America and Transamerica were separated, with the latter company continuing in the insurance sector. However, federal banking regulators prohibited Bank of America's interstate banking activity, and Bank of America's domestic banks outside California were forced into a separate company that eventually became [First Interstate Bancorp](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/First_Interstate_Bancorp "First Interstate Bancorp"), later acquired by [Wells Fargo and Company](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wells_Fargo_and_Company "Wells Fargo and Company") in 1996. Only in the 1980s, with a change in federal banking legislation and regulation, could Bank of America again expand its domestic consumer banking activity outside California. 
New technologies also allowed the direct linking of [credit cards](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Credit_card "Credit card") with individual bank accounts. In 1958, the bank introduced the BankAmericard, which changed its name to [Visa](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Visa_Inc. "Visa Inc.") in 1977.[[21]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America#cite_note-21) A coalition of regional bankcard associations introduced Interbank in 1966 to compete with BankAmericard. Interbank became Master Charge in 1966 and then [Mastercard](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mastercard "Mastercard") in 1979.[[22]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America#cite_note-Stearns-22)
From February 1970 through September 1971, there were 66 attacks on Bank of America branches in California, including 53 bombings or fire-bombings, and 13 arson fires. There were "few injuries" and the property damage cost about $500,000, 80% of which was from the burning of the Isla Vista branch during a February 1970 riot.[[23]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America#cite_note-23)
### Expansion outside California
[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Bank_of_America&action=edit&section=4 "Edit section: Expansion outside California")]
[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3c/BankAmerica_logo.png/250px-BankAmerica_logo.png)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:BankAmerica_logo.png)Bank of America's logo from 1969 to 1998 [![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e7/Bank_of_America_Tower_in_Manhattan_2015.jpg/250px-Bank_of_America_Tower_in_Manhattan_2015.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Bank_of_America_Tower_in_Manhattan_2015.jpg)[Bank of America Tower](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America_Tower_\(Manhattan\) "Bank of America Tower \(Manhattan\)"), headquarters for Bank of America's [investment banking](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Investment_banking "Investment banking") operations, seen from [Bryant Park](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bryant_Park "Bryant Park") in [Midtown Manhattan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Midtown_Manhattan "Midtown Manhattan"), in 2015
Following passage of the [Bank Holding Company Act of 1956](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_Holding_Company_Act_of_1956 "Bank Holding Company Act of 1956") by the [U.S. Congress](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Congress "United States Congress"),[[24]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America#cite_note-24) BankAmerica Corporation was established for the purpose of owning and operating Bank of America and its subsidiaries. 
In 1983, Bank of America expanded outside [California](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/California "California"), through acquisition, orchestrated in part by [Stephen McLin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stephen_McLin "Stephen McLin") of [Seafirst Corporation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seafirst_Corporation "Seafirst Corporation") in [Seattle](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle "Seattle"), and its wholly owned banking subsidiary, Seattle-First National Bank.[[25]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America#cite_note-:1-25) Seafirst was at risk of seizure by the federal government after becoming insolvent due to a series of bad loans to the [oil industry](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Petroleum_industry "Petroleum industry"). BankAmerica continued to operate its new subsidiary as Seafirst rather than Bank of America until the 1998 merger with NationsBank.[[25]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America#cite_note-:1-25)
BankAmerica experienced huge losses in 1986 and 1987 due to the placement of a series of bad loans in the [Third World](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Third_World "Third World"). The company fired its CEO, [Sam Armacost](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Samuel_Armacost "Samuel Armacost"), in 1986. Though Armacost blamed the problems on his predecessor, [A. W. (Tom) Clausen](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alden_W._Clausen "Alden W. Clausen"), Clausen was appointed to replace Armacost.[_[citation needed](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] The losses resulted in a huge decline of BankAmerica stock, making it vulnerable to a hostile [takeover](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Takeover "Takeover"). [First Interstate Bancorp](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/First_Interstate_Bancorp "First Interstate Bancorp") of Los Angeles (which had originated from banks once owned by BankAmerica), launched such a bid in the fall of 1986, although BankAmerica rebuffed it, mostly by selling operations.[[26]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America#cite_note-26) It sold its FinanceAmerica subsidiary to [Chrysler](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chrysler "Chrysler") and the brokerage firm [Charles Schwab and Co.](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Charles_Schwab_Corporation "Charles Schwab Corporation") back to [Mr. Schwab](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Charles_R._Schwab "Charles R. Schwab"). It also sold [Bank of America and Italy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America_and_Italy "Bank of America and Italy") to [Deutsche Bank](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deutsche_Bank "Deutsche Bank"). By the time of the [1987 stock-market crash](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Black_Monday_\(1987\) "Black Monday \(1987\)"), BankAmerica's share price had fallen to $8, but by 1992 it had rebounded mightily to become one of the biggest gainers of that half-decade.[_[citation needed](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]
BankAmerica's next big acquisition came in 1992. The company acquired Security Pacific Corporation and its subsidiary [Security Pacific National Bank](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Security_Pacific_Bank "Security Pacific Bank") in California and other banks in [Arizona](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arizona "Arizona"), [Idaho](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Idaho "Idaho"), [Oregon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oregon "Oregon"), and [Washington](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Washington_\(state\) "Washington \(state\)"), which Security Pacific had acquired in a series of acquisitions in the late 1980s. This represented, at the time, the largest bank acquisition in history.[[27]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America#cite_note-27) Federal regulators, however, forced the sale of roughly half of Security Pacific's [Washington](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Washington,_D.C. "Washington, D.C.") subsidiary, the former [Rainier Bank](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rainier_Bank "Rainier Bank"), as the combination of Seafirst and Security Pacific Washington would have given BankAmerica too large a share of the market in that state. The Washington branches were divided and sold to West One Bancorp (now [U.S. Bancorp](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/U.S._Bancorp "U.S. Bancorp")) and [KeyBank](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/KeyBank "KeyBank").[[28]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America#cite_note-28) Later that year, BankAmerica expanded into Nevada by acquiring Valley Bank of Nevada.[[29]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America#cite_note-29)
In 1994, BankAmerica acquired the [Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Co.](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Continental_Illinois_National_Bank_and_Trust_Co. "Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Co.") of Chicago. At the time, no bank possessed the resources to bail out Continental, so the federal government operated the bank for nearly a decade.[[30]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America#cite_note-30) [Illinois](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Illinois "Illinois") then regulated branch banking extremely heavily, so Bank of America Illinois was a single-unit bank until the 21st century. BankAmerica moved its national lending department to Chicago in an effort to establish a financial beachhead in the region.[[31]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America#cite_note-31)
These mergers helped BankAmerica Corporation to once again become the largest U.S. bank holding company in terms of deposits, but the company fell to second place in 1997 behind North Carolina's fast-growing [NationsBank Corporation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NationsBank_Corporation "NationsBank Corporation"), and to third in 1998 behind [First Union](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/First_Union "First Union") Corp.[_[citation needed](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]
On the capital markets side, the acquisition of Continental Illinois helped BankAmerica to build a leveraged finance origination- and distribution business, which allowed the firm's existing broker-dealer, BancAmerica Securities (originally named BA Securities), to become a full-service franchise.[[32]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America#cite_note-32) In addition, in 1997, BankAmerica acquired [Robertson Stephens](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robertson_Stephens "Robertson Stephens"), a San Franciscobased investment bank specializing in high technology for $540 million.[[33]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America#cite_note-33) Robertson Stephens was integrated into BancAmerica Securities, and the combined subsidiary was renamed "BancAmerica Robertson Stephens".[[34]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America#cite_note-34)
### Merger of NationsBank and BankAmerica
[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Bank_of_America&action=edit&section=5 "Edit section: Merger of NationsBank and BankAmerica")]
[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4d/Bank_of_America_1998.svg/250px-Bank_of_America_1998.svg.png)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Bank_of_America_1998.svg)Bank of America's logo used from 1998 to 2018
In 1997, BankAmerica lent investment management firm [D. E. Shaw & Co.](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/D._E._Shaw_%26_Co. "D. E. Shaw & Co.") $1.4 billion to run various businesses for the bank.[[35]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America#cite_note-35) However, D.E. Shaw suffered significant loss during the [1998 Russian financial crisis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1998_Russian_financial_crisis "1998 Russian financial crisis").[[36]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America#cite_note-36)[[37]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America#cite_note-37) [NationsBank](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NationsBank "NationsBank") of Charlotte acquired BankAmerica in 1998 in what was the largest bank acquisition in history at that time.[[38]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America#cite_note-38)
While NationsBank was the nominal survivor, the merged bank took the better-known name of Bank of America. Hence, the holding company was renamed Bank of America Corporation, while NationsBank, N.A. merged with Bank of America NT&SA to form Bank of America, N.A. as the remaining legal bank entity.[[39]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America#cite_note-39) The combined bank operates under Federal Charter 13044, which was granted to Giannini's Bank of Italy on March 1, 1927. However, the merged company was and still is headquartered in Charlotte, and retains NationsBank's pre-1998 stock price history. All [U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/U.S._Securities_and_Exchange_Commission "U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission") (SEC) filings before 1998 are listed under NationsBank, not Bank of America. NationsBank president, chairman, and CEO [Hugh McColl](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hugh_McColl "Hugh McColl"), took on the same roles with the merged company.[_[citation needed](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]
In 1998, Bank of America possessed combined assets of $570 billion, as well as 4,800 branches in 22 U.S. states.[_[citation needed](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] Despite the size of the two companies, federal regulators insisted only upon the divestiture of 13 branches in [New Mexico](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_Mexico "New Mexico"), in towns that would be left with only a single bank following the combination.[[40]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America#cite_note-40) These branches were sold to [BOK Financial Corporation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/BOK_Financial_Corporation "BOK Financial Corporation"), which operates them under the name "Bank of Albuquerque".[[41]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America#cite_note-41)[[42]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_of_America#cite_note-42) The broker-dealer, NationsBanc Montgomery Securities, was named [Banc of America Securities](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Banc_of_America_Securities "Banc of America Securities") in 1998.[_[citation needed](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]
### Banc of America Securities
[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Bank_of_America&action=edit&section=6 "Edit section: Banc of America Securities")]
